Americans and Germans hold differing opinions on countries and international organizations, with Germans generally viewing these entities more positively than Americans [10]. This divide is most pronounced concerning the EU, with roughly 70% of Germans favoring the union compared to about half of Americans [10]. A similar gap exists in perceptions of Russia [10]. However, there is greater consensus on the UN and NATO, although Germans still tend to think more highly of these organizations than Americans [10].

Views on economic powers also differ significantly. Half of Americans see the U.S. as the world's leading economic power, while half of Germans name China [7]. Ideological differences further influence these perceptions.  Conservative Americans and Germans are more likely to view Russia favorably, while liberals are more likely to favor the UN and EU [11]. Overall, there is a wide divergence in views of bilateral relations and security policy between the publics of both countries [6]. Despite these differences, a majority of Americans (69%) want to cooperate more with Germany, although only half of Germans say the same about the U.S. [5].

Americans and Germans diverge in their views on international organizations and economic powers due to ideological differences and historical factors.

Americans' perceptions of the U.S. and China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic are significantly influenced by their political affiliations and educational backgrounds. There is a wide partisan gap in how the U.S. has dealt with coronavirus [5]. Evaluations of the United States’ handling of the coronavirus outbreak are quite partisan [3]. Overall, $47\%$ of adults say the United States has done a good or excellent job of handling the outbreak, but just $27\%$ of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents hold that view, compared with $71\%$ of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents [6]. ![Democrats are far more likely than Republicans to criticize the U.S.'s handling of the pandemic, while Republicans are more critical of China's response.](image6)

Republicans are much more likely to say China has not done a good job dealing with the outbreak than Democrats [9]. Conservative Republicans are particularly likely to say China has not handled the crisis well [9]. Around six-in-ten or more in every age group are critical of China’s performance [11]. But older Americans – who tend to have less favorable attitudes toward China – give it the lowest marks [11]. ![Older Americans tend to view China's handling of the pandemic more negatively.](image2)

More educated Americans are also more critical of how the U.S. has dealt with the disease [10]. Around two-thirds of those with a postgraduate degree say the U.S. has done a poor job, as do around six-in-ten college graduates [10]. In comparison, about four-in-ten of those with a high school degree or less say the same [10]. Education plays little role in how people feel about China’s handling of the virus [1]. Rather, majorities of people in all educational groups say China has not handled the pandemic well [1]. Nearly two-thirds of Americans say China has not done a good job dealing with the coronavirus outbreak [2]. Americans who believe the U.S. can learn a great deal or a fair amount from other countries about ways to slow the spread of coronavirus [12]. ![Those who believe the U.S. can learn from other countries are more likely to view those countries' handling of the pandemic effectively.](image5)

Political affiliation and education level significantly shape Americans' opinions on how the U.S. and China managed the COVID-19 pandemic.

There is a wide partisan gap in how the U.S. and China handled the coronavirus outbreak [10].  When it comes to assessments of how well the U.S. is dealing with the outbreak, those who think the U.S. can learn from foreign countries tend to evaluate its current handling of the pandemic less positively [4]. Fewer than half (44%) of those who think the U.S. can glean information from abroad say the country is doing an excellent or good job handling the outbreak, compared with 63% of those who say the U.S. can’t learn much from overseas [4].

Evaluations of both the United States’ and China’s handling of the coronavirus outbreak are quite partisan [11]. While half or more of people on both sides of the aisle say China has not done a good job dealing with the outbreak, Republicans are much more likely to hold this view than Democrats [9]. Conservative Republicans are particularly likely to say China has not handled the crisis well [9].
![Partisan views on handling of coronavirus by different countries.](image7)
As shown in image7, there is a significant difference between Democrats and Republicans when it comes to their views on how the U.S. has handled the coronavirus outbreak, with 71% of Republicans saying the U.S. has done an excellent or good job, compared to only 27% of Democrats [3]. There is also a significant difference in how Democrats and Republicans view China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak, with 43% of Democrats saying China has done an excellent or good job, compared to only 21% of Republicans. [11].

Political affiliations significantly influence the perception of the U.S. and China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic, with Republicans generally viewing the U.S. response more favorably and China's response less favorably than Democrats.

There's a notable partisan divide regarding the U.S.'s ability to learn from other countries in handling the coronavirus outbreak and trust in international organizations [5].  Specifically, Democrats are more inclined to believe that the U.S. can learn a great deal from the international response, whereas Republicans are less likely to share that view [5].
![Democrats are much more likely to say the U.S. can learn a great deal from other nations, compared to conservative Republicans.](image3)
This difference in perception extends to trust in international organizations such as the WHO and EU, where liberal Democrats show significantly higher trust compared to conservative Republicans [2].  The graphic illustrates this partisan divide, showing that 86% of liberal Democrats trust information from the WHO, compared to only 27% of conservative Republicans [2].

Furthermore, views on how well the U.S. is handling the outbreak are linked to the belief in learning from foreign countries, with those open to learning from abroad being less positive in their evaluation of the U.S.'s handling of the pandemic [1].

In summary, there is a significant partisan divide in the perception of the U.S.'s ability to learn from other countries regarding the coronavirus outbreak and trust in international organizations, with Democrats generally more open to international input and more trusting of organizations like the WHO and EU compared to Republicans.

There are significant partisan divisions regarding the anticipated impact of the coronavirus outbreak on the international influence of the U.S. and China [1, 6]. Republicans are more inclined to believe that the U.S.'s influence will be strengthened, while Democrats are more inclined to anticipate a weakening of American influence [1].  ![Views on the U.S.'s future influence vary by political affiliation and education level.](image1)

Regarding China, Republicans are more likely to predict a decline in its international clout, whereas Democrats are less convinced of this outcome [6].   ![Most people think China will have less influence in world affairs.](image5)

The influence of the EU is expected to be unaffected by majorities in both parties [3].
 
Differences also emerge based on education level concerning the U.S.'s role, with those having higher education levels more likely to foresee a decline in the country's global influence [10]. For instance, 45% of Americans with postgraduate degrees think the U.S.'s international influence will recede [10].

In summary, political affiliation and education level correlate with differing expectations for the future international influence of the U.S. and China, while the EU's influence is expected to remain largely unchanged.

After the coronavirus outbreak, American opinions diverge on how the pandemic will affect the global influence of the U.S. and China, with notable differences across political and age groups [1, 8, 11].  Roughly three-in-ten Americans believe the U.S.’s international clout will be bolstered after the outbreak, while the same share thinks it will be weakened [8]. However, these views are not uniform.

**Political Affiliation:**
Significant partisan gaps exist regarding the anticipated changes in international influence.  Republicans are about twice as likely as Democrats to believe the U.S.’s international influence will be strengthened [3].  Conversely, Democrats are about four times more likely than Republicans to expect American influence to weaken after the outbreak [3].  ![Republicans are more optimistic than Democrats about the U.S.'s international influence being strengthened due to the coronavirus outbreak.](image5) As the image shows, 41% of Republicans/Lean Republicans believe the U.S. will have more influence, compared to only 19% of Democrats/Lean Democrats.

**Age:**
Age is also a significant factor in these predictions [11]. Older Americans are more inclined to believe that China's influence will diminish, whereas younger adults hold differing views [12].  Americans ages 65 and older are 16 percentage points more likely than those under 30 to say China will have less global influence after the crisis [12].  ![Older Americans are more likely to believe that China will have less global influence after the crisis.](image8) The image illustrates that 59% of Americans aged 65+ think China will have less influence, compared to 43% of those aged 18-29.

In summary, predictions about the global influence of the U.S. and China differ significantly among different demographic and political groups, with Republicans and older Americans more optimistic about the U.S. and less optimistic about China's influence compared to Democrats and younger adults.

Nearly two-thirds of Americans believe that China has not handled the coronavirus outbreak well [9]. There is a significant partisan divide, with Republicans being much more critical of China's handling of the outbreak compared to Democrats [2].  Conservative Republicans are especially likely to hold this view, with eight-in-ten saying China has not managed the crisis effectively [2].
![Conservative Republicans are particularly likely to say China has not handled the crisis well.](image2)
Many Americans also anticipate a long-term impact on China's global stature, with $50\%$ believing China will have less influence after the pandemic [3].
![Half of Americans believe China will have less influence after the coronavirus outbreak.](image7)
However, there's a partisan divide on this as well, with roughly six-in-ten Republicans believing China’s international clout will diminish, compared to just $40\%$ of Democrats [5]. Overall negative attitudes toward China have been rising, with $66\%$ of Americans expressing an unfavorable opinion, marking the most negative rating since 2005 [3].

Americans generally view China as not handling the coronavirus outbreak well, expect its global influence to decrease, and hold increasingly negative attitudes towards the country, with significant partisan divisions in these perceptions.

Partisan views on the U.S.'s role in addressing global challenges and its international influence show significant differences. Republicans are more inclined to believe the U.S. does too much to aid in resolving global issues, a view not shared as widely by Democrats [7]. Democrats are also more likely than Republicans to anticipate a weakening of American influence following the coronavirus outbreak [4].

The shift in partisan perspectives regarding whether the U.S. does "too much" in helping with global challenges has widened since 2013, with a notable increase among Republicans who hold this view. ![Republicans increasingly believe the U.S. does too much in addressing global challenges, contrasting with Democrats' views.](image1)

There is a stark contrast between Republican and Democratic leaners regarding the extent to which the U.S. can learn from other countries about managing the coronavirus. ![Democrats are more inclined than Republicans to think that the U.S. can learn a great deal from other nations.](image2) While $60\%$ of Democrats believe the U.S. can learn a great deal, only $28\%$ of Republicans share this view [10].

These differences extend to expectations about America's global influence post-pandemic. Liberal Democrats are especially pessimistic, with $56\%$ believing the U.S. will have less influence [1]. Republicans, conversely, are more likely to foresee a strengthening of U.S. international influence as a result of the crisis [4].

These trends indicate a widening partisan divide on questions related to global engagement and the perception of America's role and influence on the international stage, especially in light of the coronavirus outbreak.

Partisan views diverge significantly on the U.S.'s ability to learn from other countries and its global role during the pandemic. Most Americans acknowledge the potential for the U.S. to learn from other countries in slowing the spread of coronavirus [6]. However, the extent to which they believe the U.S. can learn differs sharply along partisan lines [11].
![Democrats are more likely than Republicans to say the U.S. can learn a great deal from other countries.](image6)
Democrats are much more inclined to believe that the U.S. can learn a great deal from other nations, with $60\%$ of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents holding this view, compared to just $28\%$ of Republicans and Republican leaners [11]. Liberal Democrats are especially likely to think the U.S. can learn a great deal from other nations [5]. As shown in the graph, a notable partisan divide exists regarding the belief that the U.S. can learn a great deal from other countries about ways to slow the spread of coronavirus, with liberal Democrats more optimistic than conservative Republicans.
![Liberal Democrats are more optimistic than conservative Republicans regarding the United States' ability to learn from other countries.](image5)
In terms of America’s role in the world, $60\%$ of Americans believe the U.S. should focus on its own problems [1]. However, this view also splits along partisan lines.
![Most conservative Republicans think the U.S. should deal with its own problems.](image1)
A significantly higher percentage of liberal Democrats $\left(64\%\right)$ believe the U.S. should help other countries compared to moderate/conservative Democrats $\left(44\%\right)$ and Republicans [9]. Partisan views show that most conservative Republicans think the U.S. should deal with its own problems [1].

Partisan views significantly differ, with Democrats being more open to learning from other countries and supporting a global helping role for the U.S. during the coronavirus pandemic.

Americans are divided on whether the U.S. should focus on its own problems or help other countries [4].
Views on this matter differ significantly based on political affiliation and educational attainment [2].
![Postgraduates are more likely to support the U.S. helping other countries with their problems, while those with less education prefer the U.S. to focus on domestic issues.](image6)
Six-in-ten postgraduates believe the U.S. should assist other countries, while college graduates are evenly split.
In contrast, most individuals with some college experience or a high school diploma think the U.S. should address its own problems first [3].

![Most Republicans prefer the U.S. to handle its own issues, while Democrats are more inclined to support international assistance.](image6)
More than half of Democrats believe the U.S. should help other countries, while $46\%$ think the U.S. should deal with its own problems and not assist others [6].
A majority of Republicans prefer the U.S. to deal with its own problems and let other countries manage independently [11].

In summary, Democrats and those with higher education levels are more inclined to support the U.S. helping other countries, while Republicans and those with lower education levels prefer the U.S. to focus on domestic issues.

Currently, a majority of Republicans believe the U.S. is doing too much to address global issues, while a plurality of Democrats feel it is doing too little [2]. Specifically, $62\%$ of Republicans think the U.S. is overextended, compared to $8\%$ who think it does too little, and $29\%$ who believe the amount is appropriate [2]. Conversely, $48\%$ of Democrats say the U.S. does too little, while $26\%$ think it does the right amount or too much [2].
![]()
The partisan divide on whether the U.S. does too much to solve world problems is shown in this image.

This partisan divide is a more recent development [5]. A majority of Republicans now say the U.S. does too much to solve world problems [11]. ![Republicans increasingly believe the U.S. does too much to solve world problems, while Democrats think it's doing too little.](image7)
Democrats are more likely to say the U.S. should help other countries deal with their problems [12]. As of 2020, $62\%$ of Republicans felt the U.S. does too much, whereas only $26\%$ of Democrats shared that view [10].
![]()
This image shows the trend of Americans believing that the US does too much to solve the world’s problem over time.

There is a growing partisan divide regarding the role of the U.S. in solving global issues, with Republicans increasingly believing the U.S. does too much, while Democrats feel it does too little.

Republicans and Democrats have starkly contrasting views on whether the U.S. does too much to help solve world problems [1]. A majority of Republicans (62%) think the U.S. does too much, while a plurality of Democrats (48%) believe it does too little [1].  ![Republicans are more likely to think the U.S. is doing too much to solve world problems, while Democrats think the U.S. is doing too little.](image8)

More specifically, 62% of Republicans think the U.S. is doing too much to address global challenges, compared to only 26% of Democrats [11]. In contrast, more than half of Democrats believe the U.S. should help other countries with their problems [2]. Additionally, opinions on the U.S.'s handling of the coronavirus outbreak are divided along party lines, with 73% of Democrats critical and 71% of Republicans praising the response [5].  ![Most Democrats think the U.S. has done a poor job dealing with the coronavirus outbreak.](image4)

Educational attainment also plays a significant role, as those with higher education levels are more supportive of helping other nations [3]. Six-in-ten postgraduates say the U.S. should help other countries, while college graduates are evenly split [3].  ![Those with postgraduate degrees are more likely to believe the U.S. should help other countries deal with their problems.](image7)

In summary, partisan affiliation and education levels significantly shape opinions on U.S. global engagement and handling domestic issues.

Americans express substantial concern over specific issues in the U.S.-China relationship [12]. A significant majority, about three-quarters or more, consider each issue at least somewhat serious [12].
![Most Americans believe cyberattacks from China are a very serious issue.](image7)
Four problems that stand out are cyber attacks from China, the loss of U.S. jobs to China, China’s growing military power and China’s policies on human rights which half or more describe as very serious [12]. The share who see the loss of U.S. jobs to China as a very serious problem has increased by 6 points since 2020, to 53% [6].
![53% have confidence in Biden to deal effectively with China.](image6)
Around half of Americans have confidence Biden will be able to deal effectively with China (53%) [5]. Still, this is the issue among six tested in which Americans have the least confidence in Biden [5]. For example, 67% have confidence in him to improve relationships with allies, and around six-in-ten say they think he will be able to deal effectively with the threat of terrorism and global climate change, as well as to make good decisions about the use of military force and international trade [5].

While many Americans view issues like cyberattacks and military power as very serious, a smaller percentage express confidence in Biden's ability to handle China effectively compared to other foreign policy matters.

Confidence in Biden's ability to handle China varies across demographic groups, with some groups expressing more concern over specific issues related to China [1].

Women, Black adults and college graduates tend to have more confidence in Biden to deal with China, while white adults, men and those without a college degree express less confidence, as shown in the the percentage of people who have confidence in President Joe Biden to deal effectively with China ![confidence levels across different demographic groups](image7).

Confidence levels vary across different demographics; for example, women show a higher confidence level in Biden's ability to handle China compared to men [10].
![Women are more confident than men in Biden’s ability to deal effectively with China](image7)

Partisan affiliation also plays a significant role, with Democrats showing much higher confidence in Biden compared to Republicans [7].
![Democrats have more confidence in Biden's ability to deal with China than Republicans](image7)

Americans have substantial concern across eight specific issues in the U.S.- China relationship [12]. Issues such as cyber attacks from China, the loss of U.S. jobs to China, China’s growing military power and China’s policies on human rights are seen as very serious problems by at least half of Americans [12].
![Americans consider cyberattacks from China to be the most serious problem](image8)

In summary, confidence in Biden's ability to deal with China differs significantly across demographic and political groups, with key concerns including cyber attacks, job losses, military power, and human rights.

Confidence in President Biden's ability to handle China differs significantly across demographic and political lines. Among all the issues tested, Americans have the least confidence in Biden's ability to deal effectively with China [1].

Confidence levels vary among different groups: Women (59%) are more confident than men (48%) in Biden’s ability to deal effectively with China; Black (82%) and Hispanic adults (70%) also express more confidence than White adults (43%) [11]. Also, Adults with college degrees are more likely to express confidence in Biden's capability to deal with China than those without degrees [11].

![Confidence in Biden dealing with China varies across demographic groups.](image3)

There is a stark partisan divide [3, 4]. A large majority of Democrats (83%) express confidence in Biden on China, compared to only 19% of Republicans [12]. Conservative Republicans have even less confidence (10%) than moderate or liberal Republicans (30%) [12].

![Republicans express a low level of confidence in Biden’s ability to deal with China, in comparison to Democrat’s level of confidence.](image6)

Several specific issues in the U.S.-China relationship are of substantial concern to Americans, and About three-quarters or more say that each issue is at least somewhat serious [5]. Four problems stand out as very serious: cyber attacks from China, the loss of U.S. jobs to China, China’s growing military power, and China’s policies on human rights [5].  A similar share sees China’s growing military power as a very serious problem [2]. Half of Americans now say China’s policy on human rights is a very serious problem for the U.S. [7].

Americans' confidence in Biden's ability to deal with China varies significantly across demographic and political groups, with concerns about cyberattacks, job losses, military power, and human rights being the most serious.

Confidence in Biden's ability to handle China varies significantly across demographic and political lines, and Americans have several major concerns regarding the U.S.-China relationship.

Americans express substantial concern when asked about eight specific issues in the U.S.- China relationship [12]. About three-quarters or more say that each issue is at least somewhat serious [12]. Still, four problems stand out for being ones that half or more describe as  very  serious:  cyber attacks from China, the loss of U.S. jobs to China, China’s growing military power and China’s policies on human rights [12]. ![Cyber attacks are viewed as a very serious problem.](image3)

Confidence levels in Biden vary across demographics: Women (59%) are more confident than men (48%) in Biden’s ability to deal effectively with China [7]. Black (82%) and Hispanic adults (70%) also express more confidence than White adults (43%) [7].  Those with a college degree expect Biden will be able to deal effectively with China at a higher rate than those with less schooling (60% vs. 50%, respectively) [7]. ![Confidence in Biden to deal with China based on race.](image8)

There are large partisan differences; whereas 83% of Democrats have confidence in Biden on China, only 19% of Republicans say the same [11]. Conservative Republicans have even less confidence (10%) than moderate or liberal Republicans (30%) [11]. ![Confidence in Biden to handle China differs based on political affiliation.](image4)

Americans' confidence in Biden to deal effectively with China is the lowest compared to other issues like improving relationships with allies, dealing with terrorism, global climate change, military force, and international trade [3]. ![Biden has the least confidence in effectively dealing with China.](image6)

In summary, confidence in Biden's ability to deal with China is influenced by gender, race, education, and political affiliation, while major concerns revolve around cyberattacks, job losses, military power, and human rights.

Americans hold distinct views on China's handling of COVID-19 and its respect for personal freedoms, with implications for U.S. priorities in the relationship.

More than half of Americans believe China did a bad job handling the COVID-19 outbreak [2]. Specifically, $54\%$ think China has done a bad job, with $28\%$ considering their response "very bad" [2].  However, American opinions are divided, as $43\%$ believe China has done a good job managing the pandemic [4].

In contrast, the American perception of China's respect for personal freedoms is overwhelmingly negative.  A large majority, $90\%$ of U.S. adults, believe that the Chinese government does not respect the personal freedoms of its people [9]. ![Americans overwhelmingly believe China does not respect personal freedoms.](image6) This viewpoint is consistent across different age, education, and political groups [9].

When it comes to U.S. priorities in dealing with China, a substantial percentage of Americans feel that promoting human rights should take precedence, even if it harms economic relations. ![Most Americans prioritize promoting human rights over economic relations with China.](image6) Approximately $70\%$ of Americans prioritize promoting human rights, while only $26\%$ believe the U.S. should prioritize economic relations, even if it means overlooking human rights issues [image6].

Americans are more critical of China's human rights record than its COVID-19 response, and they prioritize human rights over economic benefits in the U.S.-China relationship.

Most Americans prioritize promoting human rights in China over strengthening economic relations, and this view varies among different political affiliations [6].  Specifically, 70% of Americans believe that the U.S. should promote human rights in China, even if it harms economic relations [6].
![70% of Americans choose human rights in China, even if it potentially harms economic relations.](image3)
Conservative Republicans and liberal Democrats are more likely to prioritize human rights over economic ties with China [9].  A significant majority of both Democrats and Republicans support promoting human rights in China, even at the expense of economic relations [1]. Among Republicans, conservative Republicans are more inclined to prioritize human rights compared to moderate or liberal Republicans [1].  Similarly, among Democrats, liberal Democrats are the most likely to emphasize human rights over economic considerations in U.S.-China relations [1].
![77% of conservative Republicans prioritize promoting human rights over economic relations with China.](image2)
This bipartisan agreement on prioritizing human rights is noteworthy, especially given the general perception that China's human rights policies are a major problem [7].  There is a broad consensus that China does not respect the personal freedoms of its people [7]. Despite differing views on other aspects of U.S.-China relations, the importance of addressing human rights remains a shared concern across the political spectrum [7]. The prevailing sentiment is that the U.S. should prioritize human rights in its bilateral relations with China, even if it entails economic costs.

Liberal Democrats and conservative Republicans show different views on prioritizing human rights versus economic relations and on getting tougher with China on trade.
Many Americans prioritize human rights in China, even if it harms economic relations, and this view is especially strong among liberal Democrats and conservative Republicans [6, 7].
![70% of Americans believe that the U.S. should promote human rights in China, even if it harms economic relations.](image1)
Conservative Republicans are more likely to prioritize human rights over economic relations compared to moderate or liberal Republicans [6].
![The majority of the respondents want to see U.S. get tougher with China on trade, views differ by party affiliation.](image7)
Conservative Republicans are more inclined to favor getting tougher with China [12]. A majority of liberal Democrats prefer building stronger ties [12].
Therefore, political affiliation significantly influences views on prioritizing human rights versus economic relations and on taking a tougher stance on trade with China, with conservative Republicans favoring a tougher stance and prioritizing human rights, while liberal Democrats lean towards stronger economic ties.

Republicans and Democrats have different views on trade policies with China, as well as different preferences on whether to get tougher or build relationships.
Republicans are more likely to see tariffs on Chinese and other foreign goods as having a positive effect for the U.S. [3].  About half of Republicans say increased tariffs on Chinese and other foreign products were good for the U.S. [5]. This sentiment is especially strong among conservative Republicans [5]. Image1 shows opinions on whether tariffs were good or bad for the U.S., broken down by political affiliation. ![Opinions on tariffs broken down by political affiliation.](image1)
In contrast, Democrats most often say tariffs were bad for the U.S. [5].  More Americans want the U.S. to get tougher with China rather than focus on building a stronger relationship [2].  This opinion is particularly prevalent among Republicans and Republican-leaning independents, with 72% wanting the U.S. to get tougher, especially among conservative Republicans (81%) [2]. Image5 shows the divide between different groups on whether to "get tougher" or "build a strong relationship". ![Preferences to get tougher or build relationships with China, broken down by affiliation.](image5) About six-in-ten Democrats and Democrat-leaning independents would rather focus on building stronger ties with China, a feeling that is largely consistent among liberal and more moderate or conservative Democrats [2].
Therefore, Republicans generally view tariffs more positively and prefer a tougher stance, while Democrats view tariffs negatively and prefer building stronger relationships with China.

Political affiliation significantly influences perceptions of tariffs and international students in the U.S. Republicans are more inclined to view tariffs on Chinese and other foreign goods positively for the U.S., a perspective not shared by Democrats [3]. For instance, about half of Republicans believe increased tariffs on foreign products benefit the U.S., whereas most Democrats think the tariffs are detrimental [4]. This divide is further illustrated in image2, where a majority of Republicans/Lean Republican think tariffs are good for the U.S. , while the majority of Democrats/Lean Democrats think tariffs are bad for the U.S. ![Republicans are more likely to think tariffs are good for the U.S. compared to Democrats.](image2)

Regarding international students, while a majority across party lines view them positively, Democrats hold a significantly more favorable view, with 92% seeing international students as an asset compared to 67% of Republicans [1]. However, views diverge specifically on Chinese students; a majority of Americans support limiting the number of Chinese students studying in the U.S. [8]. Republicans are more likely than Democrats to favor these limitations [12]. Image5 highlights these differences, where a greater percentage of Republicans/Lean Republicans support limiting Chinese students in the U.S. compared to Democrats/Lean Democrats. ![Republicans show greater support for limiting Chinese students in the U.S. compared to Democrats.](image5)

In summary, Republicans are more likely to support tariffs and favor limiting the number of Chinese students, while Democrats generally oppose tariffs and view international students, including Chinese students, more favorably.

Older Americans are more in favor of limiting Chinese students in the U.S. [7].
![Older Americans generally show more support for limiting Chinese students studying in the U.S.](image4)
Those ages 50 and older are more likely to say limiting China's power and influence should be a top priority [6]. Older Americans also express more concern about China-related issues and have less confidence in the Chinese president [5, 10].  
![Older Americans are more likely to express no confidence in China's president Xi.](image6)
Republicans are more likely to support limiting the ability of Chinese students to study in the U.S. [4].
![Republicans generally show more support for limiting Chinese students studying in the U.S.](image4)
Republicans are also more likely to describe China as an enemy and to have very cold feelings toward China [4].

Support for limiting Chinese students in U.S. universities is higher among older Americans and Republicans, which aligns with their greater concern about China's influence and lack of confidence in its leadership.

Since 2018, American perceptions of China have become substantially more negative [7, 9]. The intensity of negative feelings has increased, with the share of Americans reporting "very cold" feelings toward China nearly doubling from 23% to 47% [1]. This negative trend is evident across both Republicans and Democrats, though the partisan gap has widened [2, 3].

![The graph illustrates how the percentage of Americans who feel 'cold' towards China, and those who believe limiting China's influence is a top priority, has increased from 2018 to 2021, with Republicans showing a more significant shift compared to Democrats.](image4)

Several factors contribute to these negative perceptions.  One major concern is human rights, with one-in-five Americans mentioning it when thinking about China [10].  Specifically, China's treatment of Uyghurs in Xinjiang is a significant issue [5].
![The bar graph shows that 20% of Americans associate China with human rights issues, and 3% specifically mention the treatment of Uyghurs in Xinjiang.](image1)

Economic issues also play a key role, as a majority of Americans view economic ties with China as "somewhat or very bad" [4]. Issues like cyber attacks, job losses to China, and China's growing technological power are seen as major problems [8].

Overall, American perceptions of China have grown more negative from 2018 to 2021, driven by concerns over human rights, economic issues, and China's growing influence.

Americans express substantial concern about multiple issues in the U.S.-China relationship, with cyber attacks, job losses, military power, and human rights policies being the most serious [3]. Concerns about China have been rising, with many specific issues in the bilateral relationship seen as major problems [8].

**Rising Concerns:**
**Cyber Attacks:** Concerns about cyber attacks from China have increased from 58% in 2020 to 65% in 2021.
**Human Rights:** worries about China's policies on human rights have risen by 7 percentage points since last year [1]. Half of Americans now consider it a very serious problem [1].
**Job Losses:** The perception of job losses to China as a very serious problem has also increased [3].
**Military Power:** Concerns about China's growing military power have also risen [3].

![Concerns about China's policies on human rights, cyberattacks, loss of jobs, and military power are on the rise.](image2)

**Specific Concerns:**
**Human Rights:** A significant majority, nine-in-ten Americans, believe that China does not respect the personal freedoms of its people [1].
**Economy:** Many Americans associate China with its powerful economy and dominance in manufacturing, sometimes at the cost of the environment and workers [10].  Around two-thirds (64\%) describe the economic relations between the superpowers as somewhat or very bad [10].
**Climate Change:**  A broad 79% majority thinks China is doing a bad job dealing with global climate change [6].
**COVID-19:**  More Americans think China is doing a bad job (54\%) than a good one (43\%) dealing with the coronavirus pandemic [2].

**Political Divide:**
There are significant partisan divisions on issues related to China, with Republicans more likely to favor a tougher stance on economic issues, view China as an enemy, and support limiting Chinese students studying in the U.S [9]. ![There is a partisan divide on China.](image1)

In summary, Americans' key concerns regarding China include human rights, economic issues, cyber attacks, and military power, with many of these concerns intensifying over the past year.

From 2008 to 2015, financial optimism among Hispanics has significantly increased across various subgroups, outpacing the general population [5]. Fully eight-in-ten Latinos (81%) say they expect their family’s financial situation will improve in the coming year, a 14 percentage point increase since 2008 [4]. By contrast, the share of all Americans who share this optimistic view of their family’s pocketbook prospects rose 6 percentage points to 61% during that time [5].

The increase in optimism is evident when comparing the percentage change in those expecting their family's finances to improve between 2008 and 2015 among all Hispanics and the general population. ![Hispanics' financial optimism increased by 14 percentage points from 2008 to 2015, while the general population's optimism increased by 6 percentage points.](image6)

Notably, both Latino men (+18 points) and Latina women (+11 points) are more optimistic about their finances now than they were seven years ago [3]. Among U.S.-born and immigrant Hispanics, hopeful views of their family’s finances rose by 14 percentage points to 81% in each group [3]. The change in financial well-being from 2008 to 2015 varies among different Latino subgroups, as shown in this data. ![Change in the perception of personal finances being in excellent or good shape between 2008 and 2015 across various Latino subgroups.](image7)

Economic optimism has grown roughly twice as fast since 2008 among Latinos who had completed some college (+20 percentage points) than among those with a high school diploma (+9) or less education (+11) [9]. As with perceptions of their current financial condition, older Latinos were significantly less upbeat about their short-term economic future than were younger and middle-aged Hispanics [2]. About six-in-ten Latinos 65 years old or older (59%) say they expect their family’s finances to improve “a lot” or “some” in the coming year, an increase of 7 percentage points since 2008 [1]. By contrast, nine-in-ten Hispanic adults under the age of 30 expect their financial condition to get better, a 13-point rise [1].

Financial optimism among Hispanic subgroups from 2008 to 2015 shows a notable increase compared to the general population, with variations influenced by factors like gender, education, and age.

Hispanics generally hold optimistic views about their children's financial future, but these views vary based on their current financial situation and educational attainment. Those already in a good financial position are more likely to expect improvement, while educational attainment shows a nuanced relationship with these expectations [4, 5].

Hispanics with positive current financial situations are more optimistic about their family's financial prospects. ![Hispanics with excellent financial conditions expect significant improvement.](image8) The graphic illustrates that Hispanics with "excellent financial condition" are more likely to expect their finances to "improve a lot" compared to those in "poor financial condition".

Educational attainment also plays a role. Interestingly, Latino high school graduates are more optimistic about their children's financial future compared to those with some college experience or more [10].  $79\%$  of high school graduates expect their children to be better off, while  $69\%$  of those with some college experience share the same expectation [10]. This suggests that higher education levels do not necessarily translate into increased financial optimism for the next generation.

In summary, Hispanics are broadly optimistic about their children's financial future, with current financial prosperity and specific educational levels influencing the degree of optimism.

From 2000 to 2015, Latinos have shown significant changes in their perceptions of financial well-being and experienced fluctuations in unemployment trends. Latinos have become more optimistic about their personal finances and future since the Great Recession [1]. The share of Latinos expecting their family finances to improve rose by 14 percentage points from 2008 to 2015 [4].

The graph shows that from 2004 to 2015, the percentage of latinos who believe they will be better off financially has increased substantially. ![Hispanics' perception of being better off financially increased from 2004 to 2015.](image3)

However, the median household income for Hispanics has remained stagnant since the Great Recession [5]. Despite this, optimism about their family's future economic prospects has risen faster among Latinos than the general population [4].

The graph illustrates the unemployment rate for Hispanics compared to non-Hispanics between 2000 and 2015. ![Hispanic unemployment rate is shown against non-Hispanic unemployment rate from 2000 to 2015.](image7) The Hispanic unemployment rate improved since the Great Recession, falling from a high of 12.8% in the first quarter of 2010 to 6.4% in the last quarter of 2015 [6]. Despite the improvement, the unemployment rate remains above its low of 5% in 2006 and higher than that for non-Hispanic workers [6].

In summary, while Latinos have become more optimistic about their financial future, their income has stagnated, and although unemployment has decreased since the Great Recession, it remains higher than pre-recession levels and that of non-Hispanic workers.

The economic perceptions of their well-being have increased among most major Latino demographic subgroups [1].  However, the median household income for Hispanics has stagnated since the Great Recession [2]. Despite this mixed economic picture, Hispanics remain optimistic about national economic conditions [5].  Looking at the trendlines since 2004, views of their financial situation are more positive now than they were in 2004 [6].

In contrast, the public’s view of its finances is lower now than in 2004 [6]. Image 4 shows the general public had a higher rating in 2004 (51%) than in 2015 (43%). ![The graph shows that the financial rating by the general public was higher in 2004 than in 2015.](image4)

Despite the increase in overall income, there is still a gap between non-hispanic and hispanic incomes. The median household income for Hispanics has stagnated since the Great Recession [2]. As image 2 indicates, in 2014 median household income for Hispanics was $42,500 compared to $53,700 for all households. ![The graph shows the median household income for Hispanics and all households from 2000 to 2014.](image2)

Despite the challenges, Latino adults are optimistic about their children’s future economic success [4].  Seventy-two percent of Latino adults expect their children to be better off financially than they are now [4].  Image 1 highlights that 72% of Latinos expect their children to be better off financially. ![The pie chart shows that 72% of Latinos expect their children to be better off financially.](image1)

While the U.S. Latino unemployment rate is declining, it remains above its 2006 low [3]. As image 8 illustrates, the Hispanic unemployment rate has decreased since the Great Recession, but it is still higher than the rate for non-Hispanic workers. ![The line graph shows that Hispanic unemployment rate has decreased since the Great Recession, but it is still higher than the rate for non-Hispanic workers.](image8)

While Latino perceptions of economic well-being have increased, their income and wealth disparities continue to persist due to factors like unemployment rates and stagnating household incomes.

The Hispanic community's economic situation presents a mixed picture when compared to that of all U.S. households. Although there have been improvements in certain areas, disparities persist.

**Unemployment:**
While the U.S. Latino unemployment rate has decreased since the Great Recession, it remains higher than the rate for non-Hispanic workers [7].  ![The Hispanic unemployment rate has decreased since the Great Recession but is still higher than the non-Hispanic rate.](image4)

**Household Income:**
Median household income for Hispanics has largely stagnated since the Great Recession, remaining essentially unchanged [8].

**Poverty Rate:**
The Hispanic poverty rate, while decreasing from its 2010 peak, is still higher than pre-recession levels [8]. ![The Hispanic poverty rate has decreased since 2010 but is still higher than pre-recession levels.](image5)

**Wealth:**
Hispanic households experienced the largest percentage decline in net worth through 2009 compared to other racial or ethnic groups, and unlike white households, their net worth continued to decline after the recession [8].

In summary, while Hispanics have made strides in some economic areas since the Great Recession, they continue to face challenges with unemployment, income stagnation, poverty, and wealth accumulation compared to the general U.S. population.

Between 2008 and 2015, Latino perceptions of their economic well-being generally increased across major demographic subgroups [8, 9]. There was a 17 percentage point increase in Latinos saying their personal finances were in "excellent" or "good" shape, rising from 23% in 2008 to 40% in 2015 [10]. In contrast, the share of all Americans with a similar positive view remained essentially flat, at around 41% in 2008 and 43% in 2015 [10].

Notably, young Latinos aged 18 to 29 experienced a significant improvement in their perceived financial shape, with those reporting excellent or good financial shape nearly doubling from 2008 to 2015 [2].
![About half of Latinos ages 18 to 29 reported being in excellent or good financial shape in 2015.](image6)
However, older Latinos aged 65 and older saw more modest gains in their perceptions of economic well-being, with a 37% increase in 2015 [1].

Regarding family income relative to the cost of living, Hispanic views were largely unchanged between 2014 and 2015, with about half of Hispanic adults saying they were falling behind financially [4, 12].
![In 2015, Hispanics, whites and blacks held similar views on whether family income is keeping up with the cost of living.](image1)
This was consistent with the views of the U.S. public as a whole [4, 11].

Overall, Latino perceptions of their personal financial situations improved from 2008 to 2015, although views on family income relative to the cost of living remained relatively stable.

Internet and device usage vary amongst seniors compared to all adults, with regular daily use among those online, and trends indicating social connection benefits. Device ownership among older adults differs notably from the population as a whole [2]. As shown in `image2`, cell phone, internet, and broadband usage are all lower amongst adults 65+ compared to all adults.

Even with these difference in device and internet usage, seniors who do use the internet tend to make it a part of their daily routine [7]. Among older adults who use the internet, 71% go online every day or almost every day, and an additional 11% go online three to five times per week [1]. ![The graph illustrates that among internet users, those aged 65 and above have a smaller percentage of daily users compared to younger age groups.](image4)

Furthermore, older internet users have strongly positive attitudes about the benefits of online information, with 79% agreeing that people without internet access are at a real disadvantage [3]. Also, older adults who use social networking sites socialize more frequently with others [5]. Some 81% of older adults who use social networking sites socialize daily or near-daily, compared to 71% of online non-users and 63% of those not online at all [12]. ![This pie chart indicates the distribution of older adults regarding internet and social network usage.](image1)

Seniors who use the internet incorporate it into their daily lives and believe it provides significant benefits, especially when using social networking sites to maintain social connections.

Device ownership and internet usage among older adults present a nuanced picture, with some interesting differences compared to the general population. While smartphone ownership is lower among older adults, tablets and e-readers are quite popular.
According to the text, smartphone ownership among older adults is at just 18% [7]. However, a significant majority (77%) of older adults do have a cell phone of some kind, though these tend to be more basic devices [7].
![Smartphone ownership sits at just 18% among older adults.](image5)
Moreover, tablets and e-book readers are as popular as smartphones among older adults [4]. In fact, 27% of seniors own a tablet, an e-book reader, or both, while only 18% own a smartphone [4].
![Tablet or e-reader ownership stands at 27% among older adults.](image6)

As the provided graph illustrates, the proportion of older adults who use the internet is lower compared to all adults [6].
![The graph compares cell phone, internet, and broadband usage among all adults and those 65+.](image1)
While 86% of all U.S. adults go online, only 59% of seniors use the internet [6].
In summary, while cell phone ownership is fairly common among older adults, smartphone adoption is relatively low, whereas tablets and e-readers are surprisingly popular, and internet usage trails behind the general population.

Older adults have distinct patterns of device ownership and online engagement compared to the general adult population [10]. While smartphone adoption is lower among seniors, tablets and e-readers are comparably popular [1].

**Device Ownership Discrepancies:**
-   **Smartphones:** Only 18% of seniors own smartphones, significantly less than the national adoption rate of 55% [3, 5].
-   **Tablets and E-readers:** These devices are as popular as smartphones among older adults; 27% of seniors own either a tablet or an e-reader, surpassing smartphone ownership [1, 7].
-   **Cell Phones:** The majority of seniors (77%) own a cell phone, though these are typically more basic devices [5].
![Device ownership differs notably between older adults and the general population.](image1)
**Online Activity:**
-   **Internet Usage:** 59% of seniors use the internet, which is lower than the 86% of all U.S. adults who go online [11].
-   **Social Networking:** 27% of older adults use social networking sites [4].
![Pie chart showing the percentage of seniors who use SNS, go online without SNS, and do not go online.](image2)
**Trends in Internet Adoption:**
-   **Increase Over Time:** Internet adoption among seniors has risen significantly from 35% in 2008 to 59% currently [2, 11].
-   **Broadband Adoption:** Broadband adoption among older adults has more than doubled in five years [2].
![The percentage of older adults using the internet has increased over time, but still lags behind the general population.](image4)

**Factors Influencing Adoption:**
-   **Age:** Internet usage decreases with age; only 37% of those 80 years or older use the internet [12].
-   **Socioeconomic Factors:** Seniors with low household incomes or without college education are less likely to be online [12].
![Breakdown of smartphone ownership among seniors by age, education, and income.](image5)
-   **Frequency of Use:** Among seniors who use the internet, a smaller percentage go online every day compared to younger age groups [7].
![Internet and broadband adoption rates among seniors based on age.](image8)

Device ownership and online activity vary significantly between seniors and the general adult population, though internet adoption among seniors has been growing over time.

Device ownership among older adults shows distinct patterns compared to their usage of online social networks [12]. While tablet and e-reader ownership is notable, social networking adoption presents a different picture.

**Tablet and E-reader Preference:**

Seniors are more inclined to own tablets or e-readers than smartphones [6].  In fact, 27% of seniors own either a tablet or an e-book reader, whereas only 18% own a smartphone [7].

**Social Networking Usage:**

![27% of the older adult population uses social networking sites](image4)

Only one-quarter of seniors use online social networks [9]. Specifically, 27% of the total older adult population uses social networking sites such as Facebook [4]. This indicates that while many seniors own devices suitable for accessing social networks, a smaller proportion actively engages with these platforms.

**Socialization Among SNS Users:**

It's important to note that seniors who do use social networking sites tend to socialize more frequently with others compared to non-SNS users [1].  This suggests that those who overcome the barriers to adoption find value in using these platforms for social connection.

In conclusion, while tablets and e-readers are popular among seniors, a smaller percentage actively use online social networks, though those who do tend to socialize more frequently.

Internet and broadband adoption rates among older adults vary significantly based on factors such as age, education, and income, and these rates generally trail behind those of the general adult population [1].

Younger, higher-income, and more educated seniors tend to use the internet and have broadband access at rates approaching or even exceeding those of the general population [5, 7].  Affluent and well-educated seniors adopt the internet and broadband at substantially higher rates than those with lower levels of income and educational attainment [8].
![Seniors with higher education and income are more likely to use e-readers and tablets.](image7)
For example, those 80 years of age or older, those with low household incomes, and those who have not attended college tend to be much more removed from online life [2].  Specifically, only about one third (37%) of those 80 years of age or older use the internet, and just 21% have a broadband connection at home [2].
![Older adults report more physical and disability related conditions that impact their ability to participate in work, school, or other activities.](image1)

Internet use and broadband adoption among seniors each fall off notably starting at approximately age 75 [3, 5].  Overall adoption levels are similar among seniors who have not attended college, as well as among those with an annual household income of less than $30,000 per year [2].
![Internet and broadband adoption rates vary by age, education, and income level among older adults.](image6)

In summary, internet and broadband adoption rates among older adults are influenced by age, education, and income, with younger, wealthier, and more educated seniors showing higher adoption rates, though generally, their usage still lags behind the general adult population.

Seniors' technology adoption varies significantly based on income and education, with higher adoption rates among those with higher income and more education [9].  For example,  90% of seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more go online, and 82% have broadband at home, while only 39% of seniors earning less than $30,000 annually go online and 25% have broadband at home [8].  The adoption of cell phones and smartphones also correlates with income levels, as shown in ![Cell phone and smartphone adoption among seniors varies by income levels.](image8).

Similarly, education plays a crucial role: 87% of seniors with a college degree go online, and 76% are broadband adopters, compared to 40% of seniors who have not attended college going online and just 27% having broadband at home [6, 8]. ![Internet and broadband adoption rates among seniors vary depending on their age, education, and income levels.](image3).  Even cell phone ownership shows a positive correlation with education, highlighting the digital divide among seniors [12].

In summary, internet, broadband, cell phone, and smartphone adoption rates among seniors are markedly higher for those with higher incomes and more advanced education.

Affluent and well-educated seniors adopt the internet and broadband at substantially higher rates [1]. Seniors with higher education levels are more likely to own e-readers and tablets [4].
![Seniors with college degrees show higher adoption rates for e-book readers and tablet computers.](image6)
Even among the most affluent seniors (those with an annual income of $75,000 or more), smartphone ownership is high compared to the older adult population, but lower than that of the general population [2, 9].
![College graduates are more likely to own e-book readers and tablets.](image4)
Just 18% of seniors are smartphone adopters, which is well below the national adoption rate of 55% [10]. Despite lower overall usage, some seniors have internet and broadband adoption rates equal to or greater than the general public [11]. Conversely, older seniors (80+), those with low incomes, and those without a college education are less connected [12].
![Smartphone and tablet ownership among seniors compared to all adults.](image5)
Internet and smartphone adoption rates among older adults are significantly influenced by income and education, with wealthier and more educated seniors showing higher adoption rates, although smartphone adoption still lags behind national averages.

Affluent and well-educated seniors adopt the internet and broadband at substantially higher rates than those with lower levels of income and educational attainment [1]. Younger, higher-income, and more highly educated seniors use the internet and broadband at rates approaching—or even exceeding—the general population [5].

Seniors with higher education levels are more likely to use the internet and own smartphones. ![College graduates show higher rates of ebook reader and tablet computer ownership](image2)

Smartphone ownership is higher among seniors who attended college compared to those who have not [2]. Internet use and broadband adoption each fall off notably starting at approximately age 75 [6]. ![College graduates have higher rates of cell phone and smartphone ownership](image8)

Internet usage and smartphone ownership are notably higher among seniors with more education.

Seniors with higher education and income levels show greater internet and broadband adoption rates compared to those with lower education and income, while cell phone ownership is widespread across all demographics but smartphone adoption is concentrated among the affluent.

Seniors' broadband adoption at home varies significantly based on their educational attainment and household income [9].
![Broadband adoption at home increases among seniors with higher education levels.](image5)
Seniors with a college degree show a much higher rate of broadband adoption compared to those who have not attended college [9]. Specifically, "$87\%$ of seniors with a college degree go online, and $76\%$ are broadband adopters" [4]. In contrast, "$40\%$ go online and just $27\%$ have broadband at home" among seniors who have not attended college [9].

Household income also plays a crucial role in broadband adoption among seniors [9].  For seniors with an annual household income of "$ \$75,000$ or more, $90\%$ go online and $82\%$ have broadband at home" [9]. Conversely, for those earning "less than $\S30,000$ annually, $39\%$ go online and $25\%$ have broadband at home" [9].
![Seniors with higher household income are more likely to have broadband at home.](image5)

In summary, broadband adoption at home is much higher among seniors with higher educational attainment and higher household income.

Among seniors, a higher level of education significantly correlates with increased adoption of tablets and e-book readers [12]. Seniors who have graduated from college are approximately three times more likely to own both an e-book reader and a tablet compared to those who have not attended college [12]. This trend is evident in the data, where the adoption rates increase with higher education levels, as illustrated in ![College graduates are more likely to own tablets and e-readers than seniors with less education.](image8).

Interestingly, when considering seniors with physical challenges, such as those with life-impacting disabilities or conditions making reading difficult, about 22% own either a tablet or an e-book reader [3]. This suggests that while disabilities may present challenges, they do not drastically deter technology adoption among older adults [3].

Examining technology adoption trends across different age groups over time, ![Percentage of internet users in each age group who use social networking sites from 2006 to 2013.](image1) shows how social networking site usage has increased among the 65+ age group from 2006 to 2013, though it remains lower compared to younger demographics like the 18-29 and 30-49 age groups.

Education level is a significant factor influencing tablet and e-reader adoption among seniors, mirroring general trends but also showing resilience in adoption among seniors facing physical challenges.

Educational attainment significantly shapes perceptions of workforce technologies, with those having higher education levels generally viewing technology more positively [10]. College graduates are more likely to find technology makes their work more interesting (64% vs. 38%) and increases career advancement opportunities (53% vs. 32%) compared to those with high school diplomas or less [2].
![College graduates find technology makes their work more interesting and increases career advancement opportunities more often than those with less education.](image7)
Workers with college degrees are significantly more likely to view office productivity tools, email, social media, and smartphones as having a positive professional impact compared to those with high school diplomas or less [12].
![College graduates more often perceive positive impacts from office tools, social media, and smartphones.](image3)
In contrast, only 38% of workers with high school diplomas or less find technology makes their jobs more interesting, and 32% feel it increases career advancement opportunities [7]. Just 45% of workers with high school diplomas find technologies such as word processing or spreadsheet software have a positive impact, compared to 90% of college graduates [12].
![Workers' views on how technology has impacted the demands of their jobs.](image2)
Regarding future technologies, a large majority (94%) are aware of driverless vehicle development, and roughly two-thirds expect most vehicles to be driverless within the next half-century [8].
![Most Americans anticipate that the majority of vehicles will be driverless in the next 50 years.](image1)
Educational attainment plays a crucial role in shaping perceptions of workforce technologies, while the public generally anticipates widespread adoption of driverless car technology in the coming decades.

Workers with varying levels of educational attainment express pronounced differences in their views of workplace technology [8].
![Workers with different education levels perceive the impact of technology differently](image1)
Workers with at least a four-year college degree have markedly more positive views compared with those with high school diplomas or less [9]. These differences are most pronounced in the case of office productivity tools such as word processing or spreadsheet software: There is a 45-percentage point difference in the share of workers with college degrees (90\%) and with high school diplomas or less (45\%) who feel these technologies have had a positive impact on them professionally [9].

Fully $94\%$ of Americans have some awareness of the effort to develop driverless vehicles, and roughly two-thirds of the public anticipates that most vehicles on the road will be driverless within the next half-century – with $9\%$ predicting that this will occur in the next 10 years [1].
![Most Americans expect driverless cars on the roads within the next half-century](image4)
Workers with higher education levels generally view workplace technologies more positively, and there's widespread awareness and expectation of driverless vehicles becoming common in the coming decades.

Many Americans foresee widespread adoption of automation technologies like driverless vehicles in coming decades [1]. A significant $94\%$ of Americans are aware of driverless vehicle development, with about two-thirds anticipating most vehicles will be driverless within 50 years, and $9\%$ expect this within 10 years [1].
![Americans anticipate driverless vehicles in the future.](image8)
In contrast, current experiences with technology in the workplace yield mixed reactions from workers [4]. While many have positive views, substantial shares find technology damaging or neutral to their career prospects [5]. Workers express varied views on the impact of different technologies, where substantial share of workers indicate that technologies such as word processing or spreadsheet software $\left(70\%\right)$, smartphones $(67\%)$, and email or social media $(60\%)$ have had a positive impact on their own careers [8].
![Workers have indicated that technologies such as word processing or spreadsheet software, smartphones and email or social media have had a positive impact on their own careers.](image4)
Workers generally have more positive than negative views about technology's impact throughout their careers [3, 12]. Approximately half $(53\%)$ feel technology has made their work more interesting, while only $12\%$ find it less interesting [12].
![Technology has made work more interesting for most workers.](image3)
However, the impacts are disparate; those with higher education view technology more positively, seeing it as making work more interesting and providing career advancement opportunities, while those without college education are less likely to share this positive view [6].
![Workers with higher education attainment have benefited from technology in their careers.](image7)
While automation technologies are anticipated to bring significant change, workers' current experiences reflect a mix of positive and negative impacts, heavily influenced by education level, on job satisfaction and career opportunities.

Workers with higher levels of education tend to view workplace technologies more positively [3, 10]. Specifically, a larger percentage of college graduates, compared to those with high school diplomas or less, believe that technology has made their work more interesting and increased their career advancement opportunities [5, 8].
![College graduates are more likely to find their work more interesting and have increased opportunities for advancement due to technology.](image1)
For instance,  $64\%$ of college graduates find technology has made their work more interesting, compared to only $38\%$ of workers with high school diplomas or less [8]. ![Workers with higher education levels have more positive impacts with workplace technology.](image4)
Additionally, technology has increased opportunities for career advancement for $53\%$ of college graduates, while only $32\%$ of those with a high school education or less feel the same [8].
![Technology has made work more interesting for 53% of workers.](image7)
Educational attainment significantly influences how workers perceive the impact of technology on their job interest and career opportunities.

Workers with different levels of education have notably different perspectives on how technology affects their careers [5]. Workers with higher levels of education generally have more positive views about how technology has increased opportunities and made their jobs more interesting [2, 7].
![College graduates are more likely to find that technology has made work more interesting and increased opportunities for advancement.](image1)
As shown in the image, 64% of college graduates feel that technology has made their work more interesting, while only 38% of those with a high school diploma or less agree [12]. Furthermore, 53% of college graduates say technology has increased their opportunities for career advancement, compared to just 32% of those with a high school diploma or less [12].
![Workers with a high school diploma or less are more likely to express that technology has no impact on their job.](image3)
A significant portion of non-college educated workers feel that technology has not significantly impacted their careers, either positively or negatively [3]. In fact, about 24% of workers with a high school diploma or less say that none of the six technologies asked about in the survey (word processing software, smartphones, email/social media, scheduling software, customer self-serve tech, and industrial robots) have had a positive impact, compared to only 2% of college graduates [6, 11]. Workers with higher educational attainment generally perceive technology as a positive force that enhances their work and provides avenues for career advancement, while those without a college education are less likely to hold such positive views [8].

Educational attainment significantly influences workers' perceptions of how technology impacts their work, with higher education levels correlating with more positive views on technology's effects on job interest and career advancement.

Workers with higher education levels are more likely to view technology as increasing job opportunities and making their work more interesting [4, 8]. The survey indicates that workers with varying levels of educational attainment express pronounced differences in their views of workplace technology [9].

College graduates are more likely to report that technology has made their work more interesting and increased their opportunities for career advancement, compared to those with high school diplomas or less [10]. ![Workers with college degrees found that technology made their work more interesting and increased opportunities for career advancement.](image1)

In contrast, workers with high school diplomas or less are more downbeat about the impact of technology on their careers compared to college graduates [5]. ![College graduates have more positive views of workplace technologies than those with less education.](image7)
