The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) operates under the Department of Space (DOS), which in turn reports to the Space Commission and the Prime Minister, as illustrated in the organizational chart.
![The image provides the organization structure of the Indian Space Research Organisation.](image2)
The Space Commission formulates policies and oversees the implementation of the Indian space program [5]. DOS implements these programs mainly through ISRO, along with other labs and centers [5]. The DOS Secretariat and ISRO Headquarters are located in Bengaluru, coordinating various programs [3].

The budget allocation for ISRO's different programs in 2015-2016 and 2016-2017 is depicted in the bar graph.
![The bar graph shows the budget allocation for ISRO's different programs in 2015-2016 and 2016-2017.](image1)
In Space Technology, the budget increased from 4596.2 in BE 2015-2016 to 5235.68 in BE 2016-2017. In Space Applications, the budget increased from 962.32 in BE 2015-2016 to 1034.39 in BE 2016-2017.
The grand total allocated to ISRO was 7388.19 in BE 2015-2016 and 7509.14 in BE 2016-2017.

The organizational structure of ISRO involves multiple levels, from the Prime Minister down to various centers and units, with a budget allocated across different programs, with the grand total increasing from 7388.19 in BE 2015-2016 to 7509.14 in BE 2016-2017.

The Indian Space Programme is implemented through various centers, each with specific roles and significance, overseen by the Space Commission [1]. DOS implements space programmes through ISRO, PRL, NARL, NE-SAC and SCL [1].
![DOS implements space programmes through ISRO, PRL, NARL, NE-SAC and SCL](image3)

The North Eastern-Space Applications Centre (NE-SAC) in Shillong supports development in the North Eastern Region using space science and technology [9].
![NE-SAC is located in Shillong](image1)

The National Atmospheric Research Laboratory (NARL) at Gadanki focuses on atmospheric research and technology development, with the goal of predicting atmospheric behavior through observations and modeling [2]. NARL's research activities include radar applications, ionospheric and space research, atmospheric dynamics, cloud and convective systems, aerosols, radiation, trace gases, weather and climate research, and specific projects like LIDAR and advanced space-borne instrument development [4].
![NARL is located in Tirupati](image1)
![NARL focuses on atmospheric research and technology development](image8)

The Semi-Conductor Laboratory (SCL) in Chandigarh aims to strengthen microelectronics in India, focusing on design, development, fabrication, assembly, testing, and reliability of CMOS and MEMS devices [8]. The Up gradation of Wafer Fabrication Lab has been completed and 8" CMOS Wafer Fabrication Line is geared-up for production activities [3].

The Indian Institute of Space Science and Technology (IIST) in Thiruvananthapuram provides high-quality education in space science and technology to meet the needs of the Indian Space Programme [6, 11].
![IIST is located in Thiruvananthapuram](image1)
IIST offers Bachelor’s Degrees in Space Technology with specializations in Avionics and Aerospace Engineering, and Integrated Masters Programmes in Applied Sciences with a focus on space-related subjects [6].
![IIST offers high quality education in space science and technology](image6)

Antrix Corporation, located in Bengaluru, serves as the marketing arm of ISRO for commercializing space products, technical consultancy, and technology transfer [5].
![Antrix Corporation is located in Bengaluru](image1)
Antrix provides end-to-end solutions, from hardware and software supply to complex spacecraft, and offers services like remote sensing data, transponder leasing, and launch services [7].
![Antrix engages in providing space products and services to international customers worldwide](image4)

The budget allocation reflects the importance of these centers, with substantial funds allocated to space technology and applications [2].
![The bar graph shows the budget allocation for various space programs and activities](image2)

These centers play crucial roles in research, development, education, and commercialization, contributing significantly to the advancement and application of space science and technology in India.

NARL's primary function is atmospheric research, with a vision to develop the capability to predict the behavior of the earth’s atmosphere through observations and modeling [3]. NARL focuses on technology development, observations, data archival, dissemination, assimilation, and modeling to realize this vision [3].
![NARL is located in Tirupati](image1)
The Semi-Conductor Laboratory (SCL) aims to create a strong microelectronics base in the country and enhance capabilities in the VLSI domain [7].

Activities at SCL are focused on the Design, Development, Fabrication, Assembly, Testing and Reliability Assurance of CMOS and MEMS Devices [7].
![Inside view of Semiconductor Lab](image3)
SCL has completed the Up gradation of Wafer Fabrication Lab and   $8"$   CMOS Wafer Fabrication Line is geared-up for production activities [4].

The National Atmospheric Research Laboratory (NARL) conducts atmospheric research and the Semi-Conductor Laboratory (SCL) focuses on microelectronics and VLSI capabilities.

Technology usage inside the household versus outside shows distinct patterns. Within households, mobile phones are the most frequently accessed technology, with 86% usage, followed by television at 49%, and radio at 45% ![Mobile phones are the most used technology inside the household, with 86% usage](). A significantly smaller percentage use computers (10%) and the internet (5%) inside their households [3].  Outside the household, however, 68% of people do not use any of these technologies [10]. Where available, mobile phones are used by 20%, and television is used by 11% ![Most people do not use technology outside of their homes](image7).

Radio listening habits also vary across demographics.  While 76% listen to the radio on a radio device, 40% use a mobile phone [4].  In rural areas, 77% use a radio, and 39% use a mobile phone for listening, compared to urban areas where 49% use a radio and 70% use a mobile phone ![Most rural listeners use radios, whereas mobile phone usage is higher in urban areas](image4).  This suggests that mobile phones have become a significant alternative for radio access, particularly in urban settings.

Furthermore, the time of day influences radio listening [8].  57% of radio listening occurs between 6 PM and 9 PM, with 36% between 6 AM and 9 AM ![Most people listen to the radio between 6 PM and 9 PM](image1).  This contrasts with only 6% listening between 9 PM and midnight, indicating that evening hours are the most popular for radio consumption. The radio programs that people listen to mostly are news (82%) and music (58%) ![Most radio programs that people listen to are music and news](image6). Despite these statistics, many people have reasons for not listening to the radio, including not having time, not being able to afford a radio, or not finding the programs interesting [1, 2, 4, 11].

Technology usage habits differ significantly between inside and outside the household, influencing radio listening habits, with mobile phones being a primary alternative, particularly in urban areas.

Access to newspapers and television was surveyed as part of the National Opinion Survey [2, 1, 12]. The survey asked the people of Nepal what the most important topic is that they would like to listen to, watch, or read on the radio, TV, and newspapers [3].

The percentage of people who access newspapers everyday is 9%, while 70% never access newspapers ![70% of people never access newspapers](image4).

The percentage of people who access television everyday is 32%, while 23% never access television ![23% of people never access television](image7).

Television is accessed more frequently on a daily basis, while newspapers are more often never accessed.

The frequency of accessing newspapers versus television can be compared based on the provided images.
The access to television is higher than access to newspaper [2, 6].The image shows the rate of access to television everyday [6].
![Television access frequency rates include 32% accessing it everyday, 15% a few times a week, 8% a few times a month, and 23% never accessing it.](image4)
![Daily newspaper access rates are 9%, weekly is 11%, monthly is 10%, and 70% never access it.](image1)
While 32% of the population accesses television every day, only 9% accesses newspapers daily.

In summary, television is accessed more frequently than newspapers among the survey population.

Radio has the highest daily usage, while internet has the highest percentage of non-users.

Based on the data visualization, different media platforms have varying levels of access frequency. Let's analyze the daily usage and non-users for each medium:

*   **Radio**: 46% access radio every day, which is the highest among the four media [3]. ![46% of respondents access the radio everyday](image1)
*   **Television**: 32% access television every day [3]. ![32% of respondents access the television everyday](image1)
*   **Newspapers**: Only 9% access newspapers every day [3]. ![9% of respondents access the newspaper everyday](image1)
*   **Internet**: Only 7% access the internet every day [3].

The data also indicates the percentage of people who never access each medium:

*   **Radio**: 23% never access radio [8]. ![23% of respondents never access the radio](image4)
*   **Television**: 23% never access television [8]. ![23% of respondents never access the television](image6)
*   **Newspapers**: 70% never access newspapers [8]. ![70% of respondents never access the newspaper](image5)
*   **Internet**: 82% never access the internet [8]. ![82% of respondents never access the internet](image3)

Access to various media platforms varies among people.  32% of the respondents reported accessing television every day ![Respondents report accessing television every day.](image2). Only 7% of the respondents access the internet every day [7].  While 9% of the respondents reported accessing newspapers every day [8]. ![Respondents report never accessing newspapers.](image8).

The data indicates that the Internet has the highest percentage of people who never access it.  82% of the respondents reported that they never access the internet [11].  In comparison, 70% never access newspapers [11].
![Respondents report never accessing the internet.](image6)

The internet has the highest percentage of people who never access it, with 82% of respondents reporting that they never use the internet.

People have different access patterns to media such as television and internet [4, 10, 12].  ![Icons of radio, television, newspaper, and computer are displayed.](image1)
The frequency of accessing television every day is 32%  ![32% of people access TV every day.](image5).  In comparison, the frequency of accessing the Internet every day is 7% ![Only 7% of people access internet everyday.](image6).

Television is used more frequently on a daily basis compared to the internet.

32% of those surveyed access television everyday, while 15% access it few times a week, 8% access it few times a month, and 23% never access it ![32% of the survey population accesses television everyday, 15% accesses it few times a week, 8% accesses it few times a month, and 23% never accesses it.](image8)
Comparatively, 7% of the survey population accesses the Internet everyday, 7% accesses it few times a week, 4% accesses it few times a month, and 82% never accesses it [7]. ![Only 7% of the surveyed population accesses the internet everyday, 7% accesses it a few times a week, 4% accesses it a few times a month, and the majority (82%) never accesses it.](image3)
These patterns suggest television is a more frequently accessed medium compared to the Internet among the surveyed population.

Mobile internet usage and shopping behaviors in Indonesia are intertwined in several ways. Indonesians primarily use mobile phones to access the internet, as demonstrated by the fact that 62% of internet users access the internet through mobile, and less than 10% have internet access at home [12].  This reliance on mobile devices shapes their online activities.

The graph shows internet usage activities; Social media is the primary activity, accounting for 24%, followed by entertainment at 20%, and general information at 16% ![The graph shows social media is the primary activity, accounting for 24%, followed by entertainment at 20%, and general information at 16%.](image2)

E-commerce activities are notable, as Vserv.mob i states that almost 30% of e-commerce traffic in Asia Pacific comes from smartphones and tablets [7].  E-commerce users in Indonesia prefer to shop online through social media (26%), IM groups like BBM Group (27%), and forums and classifieds like Kaskus and OLX (27%), compared to conventional e-commerce sites (20%) [10]. This data shows e-commerce has grown because of mobile usage, but it hasn't taken over the main revenue method, like advertisement.

The type of products purchased online also reflect shopping behaviors.  Apparel accounts for 67.1% of online shopping purchases, followed by shoes at 20.2% and bags at 20.0% ![The graph shows Apparel accounts for 67.1% of online shopping purchases, followed by shoes at 20.2% and bags at 20.0%.](image4)

Overall, mobile internet usage in Indonesia significantly influences how users engage with e-commerce, favoring social and IM platforms, with a focus on apparel and accessories.

In Indonesia, there were 240 million mobile subscribers by early 2014, showing continuous growth with an annual growth rate of 31.9% from 2006 to 2010 [1].

Mobile internet demographics reveal that social media accounts for 24% of mobile usage, while entertainment takes up 20% ![Mobile internet usage is primarily for social media, followed by entertainment](image3).
Also, approximately 62% of internet users in Indonesia access the internet through mobile devices, and less than 10% have internet access at home [10]. This dependence on mobile internet highlights its significance. Additionally, 92% of Indonesian internet users own a Facebook account, with almost 90% accessing it through mobile devices [10].

Mobile content preferences are further illustrated by the popularity of instant messaging, with 90% of mobile phone users using IM daily, and 60% using it multiple times a day [12]. Popular IM applications include WhatsApp, BBM, and LINE [12]. This preference directly impacts e-commerce, where users shop through conventional e-commerce sites (20%), social media (26%), IM groups like BBM Group (27%), and forums like Kaskus and OLX (27%) [12].

Revenue streams in the mobile internet ecosystem include advertisements, revenue sharing/commissions, and traffic/user exchange ![Revenue models include advertisement, revenue sharing and content sales](image4).

The relation between mobile internet users demographics and their mobile content preference clearly show that advertisements, revenue sharing are potential business opportunities in Indonesia.

Telkomsel, XL Axiata, and Indosat are the big 3 GSM operators in Indonesia [10]. ![Telkomsel has more subscribers and data users than XL and Indosat](image3)
Image3 shows the Subscribers, Smartphone users, Blackberry users, Android users and Data users of Telkomsel, XL and Indosat. Telkomsel has far more subscribers and data users compared to XL and Indosat.

Also, the figure shows the number of subscribers of Indosat, Telkomsel and XL from 2008-2012. ![Subscriber numbers for Indosat, Telkomsel, and XL decreased from 2008 to 2012](image2)
As the year goes by, the subscribers of Telkomsel, XL and Indosat has decreased.

Here is data from late 2014 which shows the subscribers and data users in millions. ![Telkomsel has the highest number of subscribers and data users in late 2014](image6)

In summary, Telkomsel consistently leads in subscriber and data user numbers compared to XL and Indosat, although subscriber numbers for all three decreased between 2008 and 2012.

Telkomsel's subscriber base and ARPU experienced changes between 2013 and 2014, influenced by shifts in user behavior and market dynamics.

The total number of Indonesian mobile subscribers grew continuously through 2014, with 240 million subscribers by early 2014 [8]. From 2006 to 2010, the annual growth rate was 31.9% [8].
![The annual rate of growth for mobile subscribers from 2006 to 2010 is 31.9%.](image8)
The ARPUs for SMS and voice calls decreased as users adopted smartphones and data-based communication methods like IM and VoIP [2, 9].
![Voice ARPU will continue to flatten while SMS ARPU will continue to decrease.](image2)
This shift towards data usage led to a decline in SMS and voice ARPU, but data ARPU was expected to increase as users consumed more mobile internet [5]. The initial reduction in ARPU was also due to a price war initiated by the government, but the market was expected to recover as data usage increased [5, 7].

The decrease in SMS and voice usage due to the popularity of data-based services led to reduced ARPUs, while the growing subscriber base indicated continued market expansion.

In the medium term, Voice ARPU is expected to remain stable, while SMS ARPU will continue to decline as more users transition to smartphones, and data ARPU is expected to initially fall before increasing with greater mobile internet usage [5].

Telkomsel has a significant number of smartphone and data users, with 35.4 million smartphone users and 63.5 million data users, while XL has 15 million smartphone users and 32 million data users, according to the 2014 data. ![Telkomsel and XL have a high number of subscribers, smartphone users, and data users as of 2014.](image3)

Trends show a continuous decline in ARPU until 2015, after which data users start opting for larger data plans, compensating for the declining voice and SMS ARPU due to increased mobile internet usage [5]. ![The graph shows the trends in Voice, SMS, and Mobile Data ARPU from 2013 to 2017.](image1)

From 2013 to 2014, both Telkomsel and XL likely experienced growth in smartphone users and shifts in ARPU trends, influenced by the increasing adoption of data-based services.

To determine how many years after the Chapel Bridge the Acropolis Museum was completed, we need to know when each was built and completed.

The Chapel Bridge in Lucerne, Switzerland, was built in 1333 [7].
![The Chapel Bridge was built in 1333.](image7)
The Acropolis Museum was inaugurated on June 20, 2009 [4].
![The Acropolis Museum was completed in 2009.](image4)

Now we simply subtract the two years: 2009 - 1333 = 676

The Acropolis Museum was completed 676 years after The Chapel Bridge.

Active learning often leads to biased data selection, especially in datasets with imbalanced class distributions [4, 9]. Figure 2 and Figure 7 illustrate this, showing that active querying strategies tend to favor specific classes, resulting in unbalanced class distributions in the selected queries [4, 6].
![Active querying strategies tend to favor specific classes, resulting in unbalanced class distributions in the selected queries.](image3)
This bias causes poor class coverage, particularly at low budgets, which can negatively impact performance [2]. The bias towards specific classes in active learning can cause some classes to be simply not selected for training, particularly in datasets with long-tail distributions [4, 9]. Therefore, active querying strategies can barely outperform random sampling because of this selective bias in data sampling at the beginning [4].

To mitigate the impact of label diversity, K-means clustering is integrated with contrastive features to ensure class coverage of the selected query [5]. Label diversity is important for designing active querying criteria, as most active querying strategies perform better with label diversity [7].
![Label diversity is important for designing active querying criteria, as most active querying strategies perform better with label diversity.](image5)
Enforcing label diversity in querying strategies can significantly improve performance, suggesting that poor label diversity contributes to the underperformance of existing active querying strategies compared to random selection [2]. Active querying strategies generally exhibit poor label diversity, leading to underperformance, especially in scenarios with limited budgets or imbalanced datasets.

In shallow layers, the significance of information flow from label words to targeted positions ($S_{p q}$) is low, while the information flow from the text part to label words ($S_{w p}$) is high [6]. However, in deeper layers, the importance of $S_{p q}$ becomes dominant [6].  `$S_{w p}$ occupies a significant proportion, but it gradually decays over layers, while $S_{p q}$ becomes the dominant one` [10].  ![Graph illustrating relative sizes of  $S_{w p}$, $S_{p q}$ , and $S_{w w}$ in different layers.](image5)

The transition from $S_{wp}$ to $S_{pq}$ dominance indicates that the information flow from label words to the target position does not dominate in all layers; it primarily becomes dominant in deeper layers.

The system produces a response to the user through several steps, starting with encoding the user's input and culminating in generating a natural language response. User input, in natural language, is first encoded into a continuous vector using a bidirectional LSTM [3]. This encoding, along with the previous system action, serves as input to a dialogue-level LSTM, which maintains a continuous representation of the dialogue state [3].

Based on the dialogue state, the model generates a probability distribution over candidate values for tracked goal slots, and a query command can be formulated and issued to a knowledge base to retrieve information [3]. ![The dialogue state tracking outputs are used to formulate a query command to retrieve requested information.](image6)

The system then produces a dialogue action conditioned on the dialogue state, the estimated user's goal, and the encoding of the query results [3].  The policy network emits a system action based on the dialogue-level LSTM state, log probabilities of candidate values from the belief tracker, and the encoding of the query results [5]. Finally, the system response in natural language is produced by combining the state tracker outputs and the retrieved KB entities using a template-based NLG [6]. This process ensures that the system's response is coherent, relevant, and grounded in both the dialogue history and external knowledge.

The system generates a natural language response by encoding user input, tracking dialogue state, querying a knowledge base, determining a dialogue action, and using a template-based natural language generator [3, 6].

The layout and information on Arizona and California driver's licenses differ in several ways, as shown in the images.

Here's a breakdown of the key differences:

*   **Layout and Design**: Arizona's driver's license has a landscape orientation with a blue header, while California's license also has a landscape orientation with a golden bear image and miner [6, 7].

*   **Information Fields**: Arizona displays fields such as "Class," "DLN," "DOB," "Name," "Address," "EXP," "ISS," "SEX," "HGT," "WGT," "EYES," "HAIR," and "DONOR" [10].

*   **Visual Elements**: Arizona includes a star in the upper right corner, and a signature of the license holder [7]. California has images of a miner and the license holder [6].

*   **Data Extraction**: GPT-4V can extract these details from the licenses, but with some mistakes, which can be improved by constrained prompting to return data in JSON format [11].

RAPTOR consistently enhances the performance of various models across different datasets, as evidenced by improvements in both accuracy and F-1 scores. In the QuALITY dataset, RAPTOR improves accuracy over DPR and BM25 by 2% and 5.1%, respectively [10]. ![RAPTOR achieves higher accuracy scores compared to BM25 and DPR when paired with both GPT-3 and UnifiedQA on the QuALITY dataset.](image2)  Similar trends are observed with UnifiedQA, where RAPTOR outperforms DPR and BM25 by 2.7% and 6.7%, respectively [10].  For the QASPER dataset, RAPTOR consistently outperforms BM25 and DPR across GPT-3, GPT-4, and UnifiedQA, with F-1 Match scores surpassing DPR by 1.8 to 4.5 points and BM25 by 6.5 to 10.2 points [3]. ![RAPTOR consistently shows higher F-1 Match scores when paired with GPT-3, GPT-4, and UnifiedQA compared to BM25 and DPR on the QASPER dataset.](image6) The F-1 scores on the QASPER dataset are at least 1.8% higher than DPR and 5.3% higher than BM25 [5].  Furthermore, RAPTOR paired with GPT-4 achieves a new benchmark on QASPER with a 55.7% F-1 score [7]. ![RAPTOR with GPT-4 reaches a new state-of-the-art F-1 score of 55.7% on the QASPER dataset.](image4) The data also indicates that RAPTOR, when combined with any retriever, consistently outperforms the respective retriever across all datasets [9].

RAPTOR improves the performance of models by increasing accuracy and F-1 scores across multiple datasets and language models.

The SnapNTell dataset distinguishes itself from other VQA datasets through several key features. It includes a wide array of fine-grained categorized entities, supported by images and explicit entity mentions in the answers [6]. The dataset is designed to test models on entity recognition and their ability to provide detailed, entity-specific knowledge in their responses [6].

SnapNTell encompasses a diverse range of fine-grained entities, each accompanied by corresponding representative images [1].  The answers in the SnapNTell benchmark are predominantly entity-centric, characterized by a greater depth of knowledgeable information pertaining to the specific entity depicted in the image as the answer [4].

Compared to existing VQA datasets, SnapNTell has a distinctive focus on entity-centric answers. ![{The image compares question-answer examples from VQA v2, GQA, OK-VQA, and SnapNTell, highlighting SnapNTell's focus on entity-specific knowledge.}](image1)

The SnapNTell dataset includes a wide range of categories, the number of distinct entities, and the overall number of QA pairs [9].  The questions are designed to be highly anonymous [9].

SnapNTell stands out due to its inclusion of a wide range of fine-grained entities with representative images and explicit entity names in the answer sets [7]. The SnapNTell dataset surpasses others in the variety of categories, the number of distinct entities, and the overall number of QA pairs [9]. ![The table compares SnapNTell with ViQuAE and Encyclopedic VQA, noting SnapNTell's superior variety of categories, distinct entities, QA pairs, images, answer length, images per entity, and anonymity.](image7)

In summary, the SnapNTell dataset stands out from existing VQA datasets by offering a broader range of categorized entities, knowledge-intensive question-answer pairs, and a focus on detailed entity-specific knowledge.

DSC consistently performs the best across various datasets. For example, in paraphrase identification tasks, DSC achieves the highest F1 score across all datasets, with minor improvements over DL for positive datasets and significant outperformance for negative datasets [6].
 

 DSC loss obtains significant performance boost on both EM and F1 in MRC tasks, outperforming XLNet by +1.25 in F1 score on SQuADv1.1 and surpassing it by +1.46 on EM for QuoRef [2].
 

 DSC outperforms BERT-tagger by +1.86 in F1 score on CTB5, +1.80 on CTB6, and +2.19 on UD1.4 in Chinese datasets, achieving SOTA performances [8].  Similarly, DSC outperforms BERT-MRC by +0.29, +0.96, +0.97, and +2.36 on CoNLL2003, OntoNotes5.0, MSRA, and OntoNotes4.0 respectively in NER datasets [12].
 

 As shown in experimental results for MRC task, with either BERT or XLNet, the proposed DSC loss obtains signiﬁcant performance boost on both EM and F1 [2]. ![The table shows the experiment results for the MRC task.](image1)
 

 As shown in experimental results on Chinese datasets, the proposed DSC loss outperforms the best baseline results by a large margin [8]. ![Experimental results on Chinese datasets are presented in the table, showing DSC loss outperforming the best baseline results significantly.](image2)
 

 As shown in positive datasets, DSC achieves minor improvements over DL, while significantly outperforming it for negative datasets [6]. ![The image shows the performance of BERT, BERT+FL, BERT+DL, and BERT+DSC on the original, positive, negative, and positive & negative combined datasets.](image3)
 

The DSC loss demonstrates superior and consistent performance across diverse datasets and tasks.

The DSC loss consistently enhances the BERT-MRC model across various datasets, including English CoNLL 2003 and English OntoNotes 5.0. On the English CoNLL 2003 dataset, BERT-MRC+DSC achieves an F1 score of 93.33, which is an improvement of +0.29 over BERT-MRC [5].  ![BERT-MRC+DSC achieves an F1 score of 93.33 on English CoNLL 2003.](image7)
The improvements are also evident on the English OntoNotes 5.0 dataset, as shown in the table where BERT-MRC+DSC outperforms BERT-MRC with an F1 score of 92.07, representing a +0.96 increase [5]. ![BERT-MRC+DSC achieves an F1 score of 92.07 on English OntoNotes 5.0.](image2)
The BERT-MRC model enhanced with DSC loss shows performance improvements on both English CoNLL 2003 and English OntoNotes 5.0 datasets.

DS-Picklist achieves the highest joint accuracy and average slot accuracy compared to other models.  The joint accuracy of DS-Picklist is 53.30% [6].  The average slot accuracy for DS-Picklist is 97.40% [12].
![DS-Picklist achieves the highest joint accuracy.](image5)
DS-Picklist assumes a full ontology is available and treats all domain-slot pairs as categorical slots, where corresponding values for each slot are found in the candidate-value list [8]. When the model has access to the full ontology, DS-Picklist shows that the method could further improve the DST performance [1].
![DS-Picklist treats domain-slot pairs as categorical slots and retrieves values from a candidate list.](image3)
Therefore, DS-Picklist achieves the highest joint accuracy and average slot accuracy.

DeClarE (Full) demonstrates superior performance compared to other configurations, particularly when evaluated using error metrics. When credibility regression is performed on the NewsTrust dataset, the models are evaluated in terms of mean squared error (MSE), where lower values indicate better performance [11]. ![The MSE for DeClarE (Full) is 0.29.](image5) The results indicate that DeClarE (Full) outperforms all four baselines, achieving a 17% decrease in MSE compared to the best-performing baselines, such as LSTM-text and Distant Supervision [12]. The DeClarE (Plain) model, which lacks attention and source embeddings, performs substantially worse than the full model, highlighting the importance of including these components [12]. For credibility classification on the SemEval dataset, performance is measured using Root-Mean-Square Error (RMSE) over confidence scores [5]. ![DeClarE (Full) achieves a lower RMSE of 0.604 compared to other configurations.](image3) DeClarE (Full) outperforms other approaches, reaffirming its power in harnessing external evidence [5].

DeClarE (Full) configuration achieves better performance with lower error metrics compared to other configurations.

The performance of 'Our Approach' on the LANI and CHAI datasets can be assessed by comparing it to baseline methods like STOP, RANDOM WALK, and MOST FREQUENT, as well as other approaches such as MISRA17 and CHAPLOT18 [10].
In the LANI navigation task, 'Our Approach' outperforms CHAPLOT18, improving task completion (TC) accuracy by 5% [1].  'Our Approach' also demonstrates an improvement on stop distance (SD) in CHAI, while CHAPLOT18 and MISRA17 both fail to learn [1].
Evaluating performance with oracle goals improves navigation on both tasks significantly; however, the model struggles with manipulation behavior for CHAI [9].
The table shows the performance on the held-out test dataset, including SD and TC for LANI, and SD and manipulation accuracy (MA) for CHAI. ![The table summarizes the performance of different methods on the held-out test datasets for LANI and CHAI.](image1)
Experiments on the LANI navigation task show that decomposing goal prediction and action generation improves instruction execution performance [12]. While similar trends are observed on CHAI instructions, the results are weaker, indicating the task's complexity [12].

In summary, 'Our Approach' generally shows improved performance compared to other methods on the LANI and CHAI datasets, particularly in navigation tasks, but faces challenges with manipulation in the CHAI environment.

The 'Ours' model generally outperforms other NER models, particularly when trained with combined datasets. The model architecture resembles the recent neural AttentiveNER model [10]. The combination of the model and training data shows a clear improvement from prior work, setting a new state-of-the art result [8].

When comparing the performance of 'AttentiveNER' and 'Ours' models using different training data, the "Ours" model demonstrates superior performance; specifically, the model achieves the best results when trained using ONTO, WIKI, and HEAD datasets, reaching an accuracy of 61.6, a MaF1 of 77.3 and a MiF1 of 71.8. ![The "Ours" model outperforms AttentiveNER when trained with ONTO, WIKI, and HEAD datasets, achieving higher accuracy and F1 scores.](image1)

Compared to other models like AttentiveNER++, AFET, and LNR, the 'Ours' model (trained on ONTO+WIKI+HEAD) achieves the highest accuracy (59.5), Ma-F1 (76.8), and Mi-F1 (71.8) scores on the fine-grained entity typing test set. ![The 'Ours' model shows the highest accuracy, Ma-F1, and Mi-F1 scores on the test set compared to other models.](image2)

The 'Ours' model achieves state-of-the-art results by combining a novel architecture with multi-task learning and distant supervision, resulting in significant performance gains.

The  $\mathrm{NCRF++}$  toolkit supports flexible feature utilization, including both handcrafted and automatically extracted features [1]. The impact of these features on NER performance can be significant. As shown in the following figure.

![The figure shows human and auto features that impact NER.](image4)

Based on the data, using automatically extracted features like CLSTM and CCNN can boost the F1-value compared to using human features, with +CCNN achieving an F1-value of 91.35 [See image4].

Furthermore, according to Table 1, the "CCNN+WLSTM+CRF" model achieves the highest F1-value of 91.35 for NER [See image3].

![The table shows different results of CRF-based models.](image3)

The "CCNN+WLSTM+CRF" model, utilizing CNNs for character sequence, LSTMs for word sequence, and a CRF layer, achieves the highest F1-value for NER [See image3].

According to the experiments, the LSTUR approach is a strong performer. The LSTUR approach can capture both long-term preferences and short-term interests, which is essential for modeling diverse user interests [6]. Moreover, the attention mechanism used in the news encoder helps in learning more informative news representations [6].

The LSTUR approach outperforms other methods, including deep learning models like CNN, GRU, and DKN [6].
![LSTUR-ini and LSTUR-con achieve the best performance on AUC and nDCG@10 metrics as shown in the table.](image4)
As illustrated in the table, LSTUR-con and LSTUR-ini achieve AUC scores of 63.47 and 63.56, respectively, and nDCG@10 scores of 41.34 and 41.37, respectively.  These results validate that incorporating both long-term and short-term user representations is useful to capture the diverse user interests more accurately and is beneficial for news recommendation [1].

The LSTUR approach demonstrates the best performance for news recommendation, capturing both long-term preferences and short-term interests.

The CO₂ emissions from training NLP models can be quite substantial when compared to everyday activities [3, 9].
For instance, training BERT on GPU emits roughly the same amount of carbon as a trans-American flight [4].
![Training BERT emits as much carbon as a trans-American flight.](image5)
By contrast, one person taking a flight from New York to San Francisco results in 1984 lbs of CO₂e, while the average human life in one year results in 11,023 lbs [4].
Training and developing NLP models significantly contributes to greenhouse gas emissions, which makes up a substantial portion of the emissions attributed to many NLP researchers [9].
Therefore, training some NLP models produces similar CO₂ emissions to activities such as flights.

Based on the data presented in the provided quotes, BERT Large achieves the highest test median score. This model's architecture involves fine-tuning a BERT classifier [3]. The claim and reason are joined and paired with each warrant, then independently processed before being passed to a linear layer [3].

The architecture classifies each warrant independently with the argument, yielding logits, as shown in the general architecture for all models [4]. ![General architecture for the models involves classifying each warrant independently with the argument.](image1)

Specifically, BERT Large achieves a test median accuracy of 0.712 [6].  The general architecture for BERT models involves processing claims, reasons, and warrants, and passing them through BERT layers [3]. ![BERT classifier processes the claim and reason, paired with each warrant.](image2)

BERT Large has the highest test median score of 0.712 [6].

The COMET model shows significant improvements over baseline models in both automatic and human evaluations [1]. The BLEU-2 results indicate that COMET exceeds the performance of all baselines, achieving a $51\%$ relative improvement over the top-performing model of Sap et al. (2019) [1]. Additionally, human evaluation reported a statistically significant relative Avg performance increase of $18\%$ over the top baseline [1].
![COMET outperforms other models in average performance.](image2)
COMET demonstrates an average event understanding performance of 56.45, surpassing other models like Event2(In)voluntary (Sap et al., 2019) and 9Enc9Dec (Sap et al., 2019) [2]. COMET also produces more novel tuple objects than the baselines [2]. The COMET model demonstrates superior performance compared to other models in BLEU-2 scores and average event understanding metrics.

The performance of BiDAF and FastQA models varies significantly between the WikiHop and MedHop datasets, and under different conditions.

Under standard conditions, BiDAF generally outperforms FastQA, as shown in this test accuracy comparison using gold chain documents. ![Test accuracy comparison using gold chain documents.](image3)

When provided with only the relevant documents (gold chain), both models improve greatly, as shown in this test accuracy comparison using gold chain documents [9]. ![Test accuracy comparison using gold chain documents.](image3) On WIKI H OP,  $B i D A F$  reaches up to $81.2\%~/~85.7\%$ in the masked setting [9].  $B i D A F$'s iterative latent interactions may give it an advantage in integrating information across documents, as  FastQA has problems integrating cross-document information [5, 12].

In summary, BiDAF generally outperforms FastQA, and both models benefit significantly from being provided with only the relevant documents.

For system-level metrics, several metrics tie for the highest correlation with human assessments for the French-German language pair, as highlighted in bold in Table 4 [3, 11].  ![Metrics with the highest correlation for fr-de.](image4) Specifically, ESIM achieves a correlation of 0.942, tying for a win with other metrics for the French-German language pair [11].  In addition,  sacreBLEU-chrF reaches 0.952, also tying for a win [10].

ESIM and sacreBLEU-chrF are among the metrics that show the highest correlation with human assessments for the French-German language pair.

Different positional encodings impact the Average Precision in DETR model. Positional encodings are transformer components that significantly contribute to the object detection performance [1]. Positional encodings are passed at every attention layer [5].
![Positional encodings are passed at every attention layer.](image1)
When spatial positional encodings are not used, there is a significant drop in AP [8]. Interestingly, passing them in the decoder only leads to a minor AP drop [8]. Table 3 presents the results for different positional encodings compared to the baseline [8].
![Different positional encodings configuration in the encoder and decoder lead to different AP.](image3)
When spatial positional encodings are completely removed and output positional encodings are passed at input, the model still achieves more than 32 AP, which is a 7.8 AP loss to the baseline [6]. Not passing any spatial encodings in the encoder only leads to a minor AP drop of 1.3 AP [6]. The impact of different loss components such as class, l1 loss, and GIoU on AP is demonstrated in the table [7].
![Different loss components affect AP for object detection.](image7)
The DETR-DC5 model's AP is affected by various configurations of positional encodings and loss components.

P ROGRAM FC generally outperforms  FLAN-T5, especially with smaller model sizes, because the reasoning plan alleviates the demands on sub-task solvers [6]. The results in Figure 4 show program-guided reasoning is particularly effective when the model size is small [6]. ![ProgramFC generally outperforms FLAN-T5, especially with smaller model sizes.](image5)

Figure 5 compares the retrieval performance of the one-step BM25 retriever used in the baselines to the iterative step-by-step BM25 retriever in P ROGRAM FC [3]. We can see in Figure 5 that P ROGRAM FC outperforms one-step retrieval on all datasets, with the largest improvement of   $37.1\%$   on HOVER 4- hop [8]. ![ProgramFC outperforms one-step retrieval on all datasets.](image8)

The ProgramFC model leverages reasoning programs that facilitate more accurate reasoning by decomposing complex claims into simpler steps, and it has better retrieval performance compared to one-step retrieval.

ProgramFC's performance is notable when compared to other models, particularly excelling in retrieval tasks and maintaining competitive accuracy while using smaller language models.  Figure 5 shows that P ROGRAM FC outperforms one-step retrieval on all datasets, with the largest improvement of $37.1\%$ on HOVER 4- hop [12].
![ProgramFC outperforms one-step retrieval.](image1)
Decomposition in ProgramFC is more effective than one-step prediction. The ProgramFC model outperforms the baseline of directly verifying claims with FLAN-T5 on all four datasets [5]. As shown in Figure 4, program-guided reasoning is particularly effective when the model size is small [7].
![ProgramFC shows better performance when model size is small.](image3)
However, it is important to note that Chain-of-thought prompting outperforms our P ROGRAM FC on HOVER 2-hop and FEVEROUS but performs worse on HOVER 3-hop and 4-hop [10].
![Model performance on HOVER and FEVEROUS datasets.](image6)

Regarding error trends, while ProgramFC generates executable programs effectively [1], semantic errors increase with the complexity of claims, especially structural errors [11]. In the sampled 300 claims, there were no syntax errors, but semantic errors were present [6].
![Semantic errors increase as claim complexity increases.](image7)

ProgramFC demonstrates competitive performance, especially in retrieval and with smaller models, but faces challenges with semantic and structural errors as claim complexity increases.

The ProgramFC model's performance on the HOVER dataset improves as the reasoning depth increases [4]. Specifically, ProgramFC outperforms baselines by 10.38%, 11.37%, and 14.77% on two-hop, three-hop, and four-hop claims, respectively [4].
 

 In the HOVER dataset, the error analysis reveals that for 2-hop claims, 71% of the programs are correct [5]. However, a significant portion of the errors are due to incorrect program execution, where the question answering or fact-checking modules fail [5].
 

 As the complexity of the claims increases (from 2-hop to 4-hop), the proportion of semantic errors in the programs also increases, particularly structural errors [11].
 

 ![Semantic errors increase with the number of hops.](image4)
 

 The table shows the distribution of error types across 2-hop, 3-hop, and 4-hop scenarios, highlighting the increase in semantic errors and the prevalence of structural errors as claim complexity rises.
 

 Overall, ProgramFC demonstrates improved performance with increased reasoning depth, but semantic and structural errors in generated programs become more prevalent as claim complexity increases.

The 'hard-to-contrast' querying strategy generally outperforms other active learning strategies, especially in addressing the cold start problem. Figure 4 shows the quantitative comparison of map-based querying strategies, with hard-to-contrast data selection yielding the highest performance among existing active querying strategies [3].

![Hard-to-contrast querying strategy yields the highest performance amongst existing active querying strategies.](image3)

Specifically, the hard-to-contrast querying strategy significantly outperforms random selection by 1.8% on PathMNIST, 2.6% on OrganAMNIST, and 5.2% on BloodMNIST by querying only 0.1% of the entire dataset [3]. Similarly, on CIFAR-10-LT, hard-to-contrast selection improves performance by 21.2% and 24.1% when querying 20% and 30% of the dataset, respectively [3]. In the experiments conducted on OrganAMNIST, BloodMNIST, and PathMNIST, hard-to-contrast data consistently outperforms other strategies [6]. Figure 14 also shows that the hard-to-contrast initial query strategy (red lines) outperforms other initial query strategies in every cycle of active learning [2].

![Hard-to-contrast initial query strategy outperforms other initial query strategies in every cycle of active learning.](image1)

Additionally, enforcing label diversity alongside the hard-to-contrast data selection enhances active learning, as most strategies have selection bias towards specific classes, leading to poor class coverage, particularly at low budgets [7, 9]. Integrating K-means clustering with contrastive features enables the proposed active querying strategy to cover 100% of classes in most low-budget scenarios [10]. Figure 2 illustrates that this strategy yields better label diversity compared to other dominant active querying strategies [4].

The hard-to-contrast querying strategy consistently outperforms other strategies, offering better label diversity and significantly improving model performance, especially during the initial query selection in active learning.

The selection strategy of demonstrations matters, and retrieval based on sentence embedding [7]. Sentence embedding and EPR surpass random sampling by a large margin [2].

The efficacy of LLMs on specific tasks can be significantly influenced by the construction of the prompt [7]. Variations in instruction, demonstration number and selection strategy, prompt format are meticulously considered [4]. Different instruction strategies yield comparable results in IE tasks [7].
![Demonstration selection impact F1 score.](image7)
Based on the results of the demonstration selection on the F1 score, sentence embedding and EPR surpass random sampling by a large margin.

The performance of ChatGPT and Codex on the FewNERD dataset are significantly impacted by demonstration selection and instruction formats, where sentence embedding and EPR largely outperform random sampling, while instruction formats yield comparable results.

To verify claims in the SCI Tab dataset, several reasoning steps are involved, along with the challenges encountered [1, 10]. The most common reasoning step is a simple lookup, which retrieves the value for a specific cell, accounting for 20.6% of reasoning steps, followed by comparison, which compares two numbers and accounts for 19.5% [6, 10].
```
![Simple lookup is the most common reasoning step.](image6)
```
Verifying a claim may also require background knowledge from the table caption and commonsense knowledge [6]. For instance, verifying a claim might require understanding that "Productivity" corresponds to the "Prod." column or knowing that random chance implies 50% accuracy [6, 10].
```
![Verifying this claim requires various types of reasoning.](image1)
```
However, claims can be "Not Enough Information" (NEI) because they lack sufficient evidence, open-domain knowledge, or closed-domain knowledge [8]. Common errors in refuted claims include incorrect calculations and incorrect approximation words [5].  The lack of closed-domain knowledge is another reason for NEI, where additional information in the paper is necessary to verify the claim [8].
```
![Reasons for claims being refuted.](image8)
```
The process of verifying claims in the SciTAB dataset involves simple lookups, comparisons, background knowledge, and commonsense knowledge, while challenges arise from insufficient evidence, domain knowledge gaps, and ambiguous claims.

The SCITAB dataset involves various reasoning functions with different proportions, contributing to its complexity [7].

The primary reasoning functions in SciTab and their proportions are shown below:

| Function Names             | Descriptions                                                                                                            | Prop. (%) |
| :-------------------------- | :--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | :-------- |
| Simple lookup              | Retrieve the value for a specific cell.                                                                                | 20.6      |
| Comparison                 | Compare two numbers.                                                                                                 | 19.5      |
| Closed-domain knowledge    | Extract information from context sentences in the table caption or article.                                            | 12.1      |
| Open-domain knowledge      | Extract additional information required by domain experts.                                                            | 5.3       |
| Commonsense knowledge       | Extract commonsense knowledge necessary for claim verification.                                                       | 5.3       |
| Subtract                   | Perform subtraction of two numbers.                                                                                    | 5.3       |
| Divide                     | Perform division of two numbers.                                                                                     | 5.3       |
| Rank                       | Determine the rank of a set of numbers.                                                                                | 5.3       |
| Different / Same           | Determine if two numbers are different or the same.                                                                    | 5.3       |
| Add                        | Calculate the sum of two numbers.                                                                                      | 4.0       |
| Max / Min                  | Retrieve the maximum or minimum number from a set of numbers.                                                          | 3.1       |
| Col / Rowname              | Retrieve the column or row name from the table.                                                                         | 3.1       |
| Trend same/different       | Determine the trend for two columns or rows, whether they are the same or different.                                     | 2.9       |
| Set check                  | Verify if a value belongs to a set of numbers.                                                                         | 2.9       |

![The table shows the types of reasoning and their proportions.](image7)

The dataset requires multiple reasoning steps to verify claims, as evidenced by the distribution of reasoning steps required for claim verification [6].

![The bar graph represents the percentage of reasoning steps, most being between 3 and 6 steps.](image3)

SCITAB's complexity is further highlighted by the error analysis, revealing common issues such as grounding errors, ambiguity errors, calculation errors, and program errors [7].

The SciTab dataset involves various reasoning functions, with "simple lookup" and "comparison" being the most common, and the complexity of the dataset is reflected in the multiple reasoning steps often needed for claim verification.

The S CI T AB dataset involves diverse reasoning patterns for both verifiable and un verifiable claims [6]. One of the reasoning involved in S CI T AB is numerical reasoning [2].
![The image illustrates an example of numerical reasoning in S CI T AB, where a supported claim involves understanding the productivity column, a simple lookup, and a subtraction to verify the claim.](image1)
The error analysis on the Program of Thoughts (PoT) reveals grounding errors (incorrect data association) and ambiguity errors as unique challenges in the dataset [1, 8].  ![The table provides the estimated proportions of error types in PoT, with grounding errors being the most common at 50%.](image5)
The error types for refuted claims include incorrect calculation results (41.7%) and incorrect approximation words (33.33%), indicating complexities in real-world scientific claims [12].  ![The table presents a breakdown of refuted and NEI reasons, highlighting the diversity of error types in ScITab.](image3)

The S CI T AB dataset's reasoning types include numerical reasoning, with common errors being grounding and ambiguity, and refuted claims often involving calculation or approximation mistakes.

The primary reasons for refuted claims in the SciTab dataset include incorrect calculation results and wrong approximation words [10]. Also, Large Language Models(LLMs) exhibit varying performance in fact-checking refuted claims, particularly when distinguishing them from claims labeled as "Not Enough Information(NEI)" [5].

The SciTab dataset shows a greater diversity in refuted claims compared to the Sci-Fact dataset, including "incorrect calculation results" (41.7%) and "incorrect approximation words" (33.33%), as well as instances where "the claim is partially right" (10.0%) [10]. ![SciTab exhibits a greater diversity in refuted claims, including incorrect calculations, wrong approximation words and partially right claims.](image7)

Open source LLMs, including encoder-decoder and decoder-only models, generally do not achieve very promising results on SCITAB, with a large gap from human performance [2]. For example, the best result for the 2-class setting is 63.62 (Vicuna-7B), and for the 3-class setting, it is 38.05 (FLAN-T5-XL), which are only moderately better (+13.62 and +4.72) than random guessing [2]. In contrast, a well-trained human annotator can achieve 92.46 and 84.73 F1 scores in the 2-class and 3-class settings, respectively [2].

Furthermore, table-based LLMs do not outperform models pre-trained on pure texts, such as FLAN-T5, possibly because of the dissimilarity between tables in scientific literature and publicly available table corpora [8].  The results in the 3-class setting are notably poorer than those in the 2-class setting, revealing the challenges models face when confronted with the NEI class [5].

In zero-shot and in-context settings, models like GPT-4 achieve higher accuracy compared to open-source models like Vicuna-7B and FLAN-T5-XL, but still fall short of human performance [2]. This difference highlights the difficulty in distinguishing between 'refuted' and 'NEI' claims [5]. ![The table displays the models' performance in zero-shot and in-context settings for 2-class and 3-class cases.](image5)

The primary reasons for refuted claims in the SciTab dataset include incorrect calculations and wrong approximations, and while some models achieve moderate success, there remains a significant gap compared to human accuracy, particularly in distinguishing between refuted and NEI claims.

The primary reasons for refuted and NEI claims in the SCI Tab dataset, and their impact on model performance, are multifaceted.

Refuted claims often stem from incorrect calculations, wrong approximation words, partially correct claims, mismatched values, or incorrect operation types, with incorrect calculation results being the most common reason, accounting for 41.7% of refuted claims. [3].  NEI claims are primarily due to insufficient matching evidence, lack of open-domain knowledge, and lack of closed-domain knowledge [5].
![The table details refuted and NEI reasons along with their proportions.](image6)

The challenges in handling NEI claims significantly affect model performance [10].  Models often struggle to distinguish between 'refuted' and 'NEI' claims, leading to diminished confidence and shifts in predictions [10].  InstructGPT tends to classify supported and refuted claims as ‘NEI’, indicating a lack of confidence, while GPT-4 tends to misclassify NEI claims as either supported or refuted, showing overconfidence [7].
![Confusion matrices show label distribution percentages for InstructGPT and GPT-4.](image7)

In zero-shot 3-class classification, open source LLMs do not achieve promising results, with a large gap from human performance [12].  The best result in the 3-class setting is 38.05 (FLAN-T5-XL), which is only moderately better (+4.72) than random guessing [12]. As shown in the following table.
![This table shows the models and their 2-class and 3-class classification performance in zero-shot and in-context settings.](image1)

The reasons for refuted and NEI claims, such as incorrect calculations and insufficient evidence, pose significant challenges that negatively impact model performance in zero-shot 3-class classification.

InstructGPT and GPT-4 have different patterns of errors in the zero-shot 3-class setting [6].
![Confusion matrices for InstructGPT and GPT-4 under the zero-shot 3-class setting, showing the label distribution percentage for each model.](image8)
InstructGPT tends to classify supported and refuted claims as 'NEI', indicating a "less confident" approach [6].  In contrast, GPT-4 exhibits "over confidence", incorrectly categorizing NEI claims as either supported or refuted [6].  The key challenge for both models is distinguishing whether a claim is verifiable [6].  This is further supported by the error analysis on Program-of-Thought, which revealed unique challenges in the dataset such as dealing with ambiguous claims [8].  The difficulties posed by the ambiguous nature of scientific claims contribute to grounding errors [5].
Therefore, InstructGPT is less confident and classifies claims as "NEI", while GPT-4 is overconfident and incorrectly classifies "NEI" claims, and both models struggle with claim verification and ambiguity.

InstructGPT and GPT-4 show distinct performance patterns and error types in zero-shot 3-class classification tasks on the S CI T AB dataset [1].

Both InstructGPT and GPT-4 struggle with accurately predicting the NEI (Not Enough Information) class [1].  InstructGPT tends to be "less confident," often classifying supported and refuted claims as NEI, whereas GPT-4 exhibits overconfidence, incorrectly categorizing NEI claims as either supported or refuted [1].

The confusion matrices for InstructGPT and GPT-4 show that InstructGPT frequently classifies claims as 'NEI', suggesting a tendency to avoid committing to a definitive supported or refuted classification. On the other hand, GPT-4 often misclassifies NEI claims as either supported or refuted, indicating a bias towards making a determination even when information is lacking.

![InstructGPT displays a pattern of “less confident”, frequently classifying supported and refuted claims as ‘NEI’, while GPT-4 exhibits over confidence, incorrectly categorizing NEI claims as either supported or refuted.](image3)

These differences suggest that InstructGPT prioritizes precision over recall, opting for the safer 'NEI' classification when uncertain, while GPT-4 favors recall over precision, attempting to classify every claim even at the risk of being incorrect.
InstructGPT is less confident and tends to classify claims as NEI, whereas GPT-4 is overconfident and often misclassifies NEI claims as either supported or refuted.

InstructGPT and GPT-4 encounter difficulties in predicting the NEI class accurately, but their error patterns differ [5]. `InstructGPT` often classifies supported and refuted claims as ‘NEI’, showing "less confident" predictions, while `GPT-4` exhibits "over confidence", incorrectly categorizing NEI claims as either supported or refuted [5]. The confusion matrices for InstructGPT and GPT-4 in the zero-shot 3-class setting are shown below:

![Confusion matrices for InstructGPT and GPT-4 show the distribution of predicted labels versus gold labels, highlighting difficulties in accurately predicting the NEI class.](image7)

Distinguishing whether a claim is verifiable is a key challenge for both models within the S CI T AB dataset [5]. The inherent difficulty in distinguishing between 'refuted' and 'NEI' claims leads to diminished confidence in models, shifting predictions from ‘supported/refuted’ to ‘NEI’ [6]. The process to construct Not Enough Info (NEI) claims involves InstructGPT to generate candidate claims, which are then manually verified to ensure they are un-verifiable with respect to the table [9].

![The process to construct Not Enough Info (NEI) claims involves InstructGPT to generate candidate claims, which are then manually verified.](image5)

InstructGPT tends to be less confident and frequently misclassifies supported and refuted claims as NEI, whereas GPT-4 is overconfident and incorrectly classifies NEI claims as supported or refuted.

Llama 2-Chat models demonstrate competitive safety performance compared to other open-source models and are even on par with some closed-source models [7]. The open release of LLMs, when done safely, can be a net benefit to society [4].

To improve model safety, Llama 2-Chat undergoes safety-specific data annotation and tuning, red-teaming, and iterative evaluations [7].  The models become safer in responding to unsafe prompts as more safety data is used, learning to refuse to generate offensive content [3].   ![Llama 2-Chat models generally have lower violation percentages compared to other models.](image1)

Multi-turn conversations are generally more likely to induce unsafe responses across models, but Llama 2-Chat still performs well compared to baselines, especially in multi-turn conversations [2]. The model sometimes has relatively more violations under the unqualified advice category due to a lack of appropriate disclaimers [2].  ![This image shows the safety and helpfulness axes, measured by in-house reward models.](image6)

Llama 2-Chat models are optimized for dialogue use cases and outperform open-source chat models on most benchmarks, potentially serving as a substitute for closed-source models based on helpfulness and safety evaluations [1].  The development of Llama 2 includes a detailed description of the fine-tuning methodology and approach to improving LLM safety [7].

Llama 2-Chat models have comparable or lower overall violation percentages across model sizes compared to models like ChatGPT and Falcon [8].  ![This image shows safety win rates when comparing Llama 2 models against other models.](image4)

Llama 2-Chat models achieve competitive safety through safety-specific data annotation, tuning, red-teaming, and iterative evaluations.

The Llama 2 model demonstrates varying environmental impacts and performance levels compared to other models. Llama 2 models outperform Llama 1 models, with the 70B parameter model showing improvements on MMLU and BBH benchmarks [6].  The Llama 2 family of models required a cumulative 3.3M GPU hours and emitted an estimated $539\,t CO_{\mathrm{2}}e q$ [7]. Meta has offset these emissions through its sustainability program [7].

In terms of toxicity and truthfulness, Llama 2-Chat models exhibit enhanced performance, showcasing improvements in truthfulness and a significant reduction in toxic generations compared to pre-trained Llama 2 models [1]. The percentage of toxic generations is effectively 0% for Llama 2-Chat across all sizes [1]. When compared to Falcon and MPT models, the fine-tuned Llama 2-Chat shows the best performance in terms of toxicity and truthfulness [1].

Llama 2 70B results are on par or better than PaLM (540B) on almost all benchmarks, but there remains a performance gap between Llama 2 70B and GPT-4 and PaLM-2-L [9].

The Llama 2 7B and 30B models also outperform MPT models of corresponding sizes on most categories except code benchmarks, and they outperform Falcon 7B and 40B models on all benchmark categories [3]. Additionally, the Llama 2 70B model outperforms all open-source models [3].

The removal of knowledge elements impacts precision, recall, and F1-Score, influencing the model's capacity to manage absent knowledge, particularly within the 'Conscious Incompetence' setting. 

As knowledge is removed, precision and F1-Score increase, while recall remains stable, showing that the model is better at locating absent knowledge when more is missing from the knowledge graph ![Precision and F1-Score exhibit an upward trend as more knowledge is removed, while recall remains stable.](image1). The impact of poor retrieval quality is more significant on recall than on precision, indicating the model can filter out incorrect knowledge [1]. This is further supported by the data in Figure 7, which demonstrates a clear downward trend in recall as retrieval accuracy decreases ![Recall decreases with retrieval accuracy.](image7).

When required knowledge is removed, citation precision and recall drop drastically, showing the coverage issue poses a challenge to generating answers with high quality citations [9]. In contrast, the ability of LLMs to identify absent knowledge to a limited extent keeps recall stable regardless of the number of absent knowledge elements, as shown in Figure 4 [10].

The removal of knowledge elements highlights the increasing effectiveness of the "Conscious Incompetence" setting as the coverage of the attribution source becomes worse [6].

The removal of knowledge elements leads to changes in precision, recall, and F1-Score, revealing insights into the model's ability to handle absent knowledge through the 'Conscious Incompetence' setting.

The performance of models on MAVEN-ERE and Causal-TimeBank datasets is significantly influenced by the incorporation of logical constraints and the number of demonstration samples. As shown in Figure 6, increasing the number of demonstrations from 1 to 5 leads to a notable improvement, with diminishing returns beyond 10 demonstrations [1]. Moreover, the performance of models like LlaMA2-13B and Vicuna-13B improves greatly after being trained on LLM-LR [3].

The image `![The number of demonstration samples and the logical constraints will influence the performance of the models.]()` illustrates that the performance of incorporating logical constraints with fewer demonstrations can surpass that of prompts with only a larger number of demonstrations [1]. This is further supported by the finding that adding logical constraints into LLM instructions can provide stable improvements, especially with more demonstrations [1].

Furthermore, directly conveying constraints to LLMs is more effective than adding post-processing operations based on the results [12].  For example,  the performance of GPT-4 (CoT w. logical constraints) could even surpass that of the fully fine-tuned baseline on the Proof writer dataset [10]. Therefore, how to obtain the relevant logic and utilize them for LLMs are critical in solving reasoning tasks [8].

Incorporating relevant logic into LLM instructions is highly beneficial for solving reasoning tasks, with performance gains observed on datasets like MAVEN-ERE and Proof Writer [8].

The use of retrieval-based approaches to incorporate logical constraints into LLM instruction significantly reduces logical inconsistency and improves overall performance on both event relation extraction and deductive reasoning tasks [1].
![The table displays the Micro-F1 (%) and LI (%) results for different models on MAVEN-ERE and Causal-TimeBank datasets using all logical constraints, retrieved logical constraints, and post-processing.](image1)
However, while post-processing guarantees the absence of logical conflicts, it may severely affect the quality of the whole generation [1]. As shown in the Table, post-processing method guarantees LI of 0%, it has a lower Micro-F1 score compared to the approach of using all logical constraints and retrieved logical constraints [1]. For example, in the MAVEN-ERE dataset, GPT-4 achieves a Micro-F1 score of 37.3% with all logical constraints, 33.5% with retrieved logical constraints, but only 17.0% with post-processing [1].

In conclusion, incorporating logical constraints, especially through retrieval-based approaches, is more effective in enhancing logical consistency and maintaining the quality of generated answers compared to relying solely on post-processing methods [1].
